QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPRECIATION OF AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR: WAGE INDEXATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that any benefit to the competitive positions of Australian industries from the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar will be irretrievably lost if resultant cost increases are passed on by means of full wage indexation? Will the Government therefore argue at future national wage case hearings before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that increases should be discounted to take into account the effect of that depreciation on the consumer price index?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for his question. He raised a matter of importance and I want to treat it with the seriousness which it deserves. I am glad that contained in the question is the acknowledgement that any sensible understanding of what has been happening to the level of the Australian dollar has to recognise that there are some minuses and some pluses. The honourable member's question acknowledges that, with the decline in the value of the dollar, there are some advantages in terms of increased competitiveness. It is a valid question for the honourable member to ask what is the relationship between that and the approach that the wage fixing authorities will take. I simply want to say to the honourable member that the Government is yet to finalise its position in these matters. I do not believe that in this case it is appropriate that we should potentially undermine the very substantial adherence that there has been to the prices and incomes accord.

ANSWER.PARA: I know that there are differences between the honourable member and this side of the House as to the efficacy of the prices and incomes accord. At the start of this Parliament, I simply want to put firmly on record again our belief that the prices and incomes accord and the substantial adherence to that accord by the overwhelming majority of the trade union movement in this country have been centrally important in the significant economic recovery that has been made. So when one looks at a question such as this, which has been raised by the honourable member and which may have some superficial attraction about it-I accept the way in which the honourable member puts it-nevertheless, one has to put against that the importance, in our judgment, of ensuring adherence to the accord. We are not going to do anything to jeopardise that. We will, in drawing up our final position for the Commission, take those things into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of statements made over the weekend by the Opposition, supporting the stand taken by militant surgeons in the New South Wales hospitals dispute? Will the Minister advise the House whether the Government supports the stand taken by militant surgeons? Does the Government support conciliation and negotiation as the surest way of settling this tragic dispute to end the suffering of the sick, injured and poor in the New South Wales public hospital system caused by the selfish actions of these militant surgeons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. It has been clear for some time who the shepherd is in this dispute. Over the weekend it became clear who the sheep are, that is, members of Her Majesty's Opposition. Members of the Opposition have been herded into that pen, not by their Leader, not by the shadow Minister for Health, but by the shadow, shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Mackellar. The statement of the honourable member for Mackellar on this issue was the most irresponsible and inflammatory statement made in a difficult industrial situation that I can remember in my time as a member of this Parliament. That statement was designed to support the militant surgeons. The honourable member for Mackellar did his best to torpedo and sabotage the efforts at a conciliated settlement in the difficult New South Wales hospitals dispute. I notice, unfortunately, that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia has added his support to those efforts to sabotage conciliation. I will look at what the Australian Medical Association asked for and what these people are repudiating. Dr Thompson said:

ANSWER.PARA: The standing and welfare of the medical profession depends on two basic principles stated in the Code of Ethics adopted by the Association.
'I will practise my profession with conscience and dignity.'
'The health of my patient will be my first consideration.'

These principles are in jeopardy. Yet the honourable member for Mackellar and all other members of the Opposition support the rejection of that call by Dr Thompson. In fact, they support the undermining of those principles to which he has drawn attention. Dr Thompson went on to say:
Nevertheless I believe with the strongest conviction that the path down which the profession has been proceeding--
now with the support of the honourable member for Mackellar and most members of the Liberal Opposition-
will lead to disaster.
The only rational course of action for sensible men and women is to negotiate to establish a firm basis to ensure the viability of private practice.

That statement and that effort of conciliation, in what is a difficult situation, has been challenged and undermined by people such as the honourable member for Mackellar. This Government has had real conflict with the AMA. One just needs to look at the record to see that there has been dispute and difference with the AMA over Medicare, something which in many ways was to be expected. But this statement is an honest effort by the leaders of the AMA to seek a negotiated settlement in this dispute-it has proved impossible-with the representatives of other organisations. It is not simply a decision of the AMA itself. Most of the senior colleges have supported the call for a moratorium on resignations and an effort to secure a negotiated settlement. Today I received a telex from the Association of University Clinical Professors of Australia.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Opposition members are prepared to disparage every statement made by any responsible member of the medical profession except the militant surgeons in New South Wales. The telex states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Association of University Clinical Professors of Australia strongly supports the action taken by the AMA, the Commonwealth Government and the Government of New South Wales in entering into immediate negotiation to resolve the crisis in the provision of medical services in New South Wales hospitals.

Support has also come from other senior colleges. In this dispute the Prime Minister, the members of the New South Wales Government and I have negotiated exhaustively with the procedural specialists in New South Wales to try to establish the basis for a settlement. But it has become increasingly clear, as the Prime Minister has said, that those specialists simply want to tear up Medicare. Indeed, from the very outset, they have never given Medicare a chance in New South Wales. From the very beginning their efforts have been to dismantle and to destroy it. This Government stands for rational and sensible negotiations and such negotiations will proceed tomorrow with the Australian Medical Association. We are confronted with a group of militant surgeons in New South Wales who have made it clear-they are on the record on this-that in pursuit of their own interests they are prepared to destroy the public hospital system in New South Wales and to ensure that this Government is forced to bow to their dictation by their making people in New South Wales suffer. The Federal Opposition has now underwritten that position with support for that militant group.

Finally, I say to the Leader of the Opposition that, if he does not repudiate his shadow Minister, he will achieve a double standard in these industrial issues in this country. Every ordinary working man who takes action to improve his position is condemned by the Opposition as militant and disruptive. Honourable members know how the Opposition treats any effort at conciliation there; of course, it supports it. But there is a double standard. Ordinary working people and trade unionists are simply attacked as militants and denigrated by this Opposition. But for militant surgeons, for those in the wealthy sections of the community, there is another standard. In contrast to how the Opposition treats ordinary trade unionists and their actions, it will support wealthy militant surgeons in their bringing the hospital system to its knees. Let it be clear that, if the Leader of the Opposition does not repudiate that double standard in these forms of industrial relations, neither the community nor, in fact ultimately, the medical profession will have any respect for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the Minister confirm that he was advised by American officials, while he was visiting the United States of America, that his Government had approved Australia's co-operation in the MX missile tests in July of 1983? Will he confirm that he subsequently wrote to the Prime Minister in October 1983 protesting against the decision?

—Any contact involving the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and myself on the subject of the MX missile test would be a classified matter. However, to relieve the anxiety of the Leader of the Opposition, I draw his attention to the statement made on Friday by the Prime Minister in this Parliament in which, I believe, he made it unambiguously clear that there had been no such agreement. He pointed out that if there had been such an agreement how would critics like the Leader of the Opposition explain away the fact that State Department and Defense Department officials of the United States came to Australia in October 1983 to inquire as to whether an agreement could be concluded.

—My question is to the Minister for Health. Can the Minister inform the House whether he has received the report of the clinical committee on the possible establishment of a national liver transplant unit? Can the Minister also advise the House as to the recommendation of that Committee on where that unit should be located?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the clinical committee on the possible establishment of a national liver transplant unit was delivered to me in December. I thought that certain supplementary questions required answering before a decision was made. I received that supplementary report this month. This committee was made up of clinical and scientific experts from all mainland States. It concluded that a human liver transplantation unit should commence in Australia as a pilot program with transplantation, initially, being offered to adults and children at the same centre.

ANSWER.PARA: Six hospitals made proposals in relation to this liver transplant unit, three from New South Wales and one each from Victoria, Queensland and South Australia. The committee reported that all proposals were of a high standard and that ultimately each could develop liver transplantation centres in the future when a need for additional centres is demonstrated. However, the committee was of the opinion that the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital combined with the Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children in Sydney was closest to the ideal model for a national liver transplantation centre and that it had the greatest potential for development as a centre of excellence.

The committee has therefore recommended to the Government that, providing certain conditions are met, a pilot program be established in those hospitals. If that pilot program is successful, it would lead to the designation of those hospitals as a national centre, followed by centres in other States as the need was demonstrated. I endorse the decision by the committee and we will be holding discussions with the New South Wales Government about the establishment of that pilot unit. One final point I would like to stress is that this is to be a national unit and so will cater for patients from across Australia. Therefore, we hope that each State government will co-operate with the recommendations of the clinical committee, that there be an assessment panel in each State and that there be a register of those patients so that this facility will be open not just to the people of New South Wales, but to people throughout Australia. The Government will accept its obligations in relation to that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISITS BY NUCLEAR SHIPS TO AUSTRALIAN STATES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. As far as the position of Australia is concerned in regard to the access of visiting warships from the United States, there is complete amity between ourselves and the United States Government.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister and concerns youth unemployment. What are the Government's plans for implementing the recommendations of the report of the Kirby Committee to Review Productivity and Innovation Programs? What benefits will occur, particularly for Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Melbourne for his question. The Government announced last month that it endorsed the central recommendation of the Kirby report for a system of traineeships for young people. We believe that is an imaginative response to the problems young people face in getting broad experience, acquiring training and life skills. Under the leadership of my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations the Government is holding extensive consultations with employers, the trade unions, the States and the educational authorities on the implementation of the report. We hope to have more detailed proposals for implementation of this scheme as soon as possible. I hope that the Opposition shares our belief that the Kirby report is, indeed, outstanding. It certainly covers the field very well and, I believe, makes a number of very sensible suggestions, the most outstanding one being, I think, the traineeship recommendation.

ANSWER.PARA: We are indebted to the Premier of Victoria for having made available Mr Kirby to undertake this investigation for the Government and the people of Australia. It is appropriate that it should come from Victoria because the Victorian Government has an excellent record on unemployment matters. In January, Victoria's unemployment rate was 7.8 per cent, easily the lowest of any State. Victoria's youth unemployment rate was also the lowest of any State. It is from that basis that the Premier has been able to offer the youth guarantee scheme, which is an unprecedented guarantee that the Victorian Government, in its next term, will provide some combination of work, education or training for all young people between the ages of 15 and 18. I would only conclude that that very substantial and realistic proposal of the youth guarantee scheme stands in total contrast to the gimmickry of the Liberal Opposition's youth employment scheme, a scheme which would only slash wages for young people through half-price jobs and would do no more than simply change the profile of unemployment and transfer it to older people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Is the Government's export uranium policy consistent with the Euratom agreement? Has the Government ever sought a review of that agreement? What are the facts on the resale of uranium to France under the Euratom agreement?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, although not for his rather hysterical outburst last week when he tried to take advantage of a particular development which occurred whereby a German company, Urangesellschaft, was trying to exploit a political situation for its own commercial advantage. In relation to the particular matter which is at the heart of this question, the situation is that the German company, which has a contract with the Ranger partners-Energy Resources of Australia-to purchase uranium has always had uranium excess to its own requirements involved in that contract. On this occasion, the company went to extraordinary lengths to indicate to the Government and to ERA that it was intending to on-sell some of that excess uranium to a French firm. We had to ensure that, whatever the intermediary arrangements in relation to that French firm, there was no end user of that uranium in France. We have been able to establish that beyond any doubt at all, not only from the sole authorised French user of Australian uranium, if it were not for the ban in France, but also from the central agency in France which is responsible for the control of the movement and use of uranium within that country. It is perfectly clear from all those sources that the end use of this uranium will not be in France and, therefore, only one conclusion can be drawn, that is, that this was a ruse and a ploy which the German company was trying to employ in order to get out of its legitimate contract with ERA. We will not allow such legitimate transactions to be exploited by foreign companies. Therefore, I am rather surprised and a little disappointed that the honourable member for Groom and one of his colleagues in the Senate should automatically take the side of a foreign firm, a German firm, which was in fact trying to seriously disadvantage an Australian company. What we have done is perfectly proper, that is, ensure that the ban in relation to the use of uranium in France remains intact. That, I am absolutely convinced, will be the case.

I assume that the Sydney Morning Herald would have published this had it been the result of an illegal phone tap, rather than an authorised statement. But more importantly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Prospect should come to the point of his question.

—Can the Minister inform the House as to the approach that the Federal and New South Wales governments will take in their negotiations with the Australian Medical Association this week? Will this approach be based on the fact that there has been a significant shift in hospitals from fee-for-service to the lower sessional payment method over the last three years, that is, even before the introduction of Medicare?

—It is not for me to comment on feuds within the medical profession. In answer to the specific points of the honourable member's question, yes, it is true that over the last three years there has been a shift in status within the public hospitals from private status to public status, and this has been accelerated by Medicare. We have indicated clearly to the profession, in all our negotiations with it, that we and the New South Wales Government were perfectly prepared to make adjustments both to the number of sessions provided and to the sessional fee to compensate for these shifts. In addition, from the outset of negotiations we have made it clear that we were perfectly prepared to consider proposals to ensure that privately insured patients were treated as private patients, unless, of course, they opted to be treated as public patients, which is a freedom we believe they should possess.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to the 10 January 1985 statement of the Australian Public Service Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, wherein the Commission concluded:

QUESTION.PARA: We have come to the conclusion that the history of the market relied on by the applicants does not support the claims.

Against the background of that very clear statement on the merits of the Public Service wage claim, I ask the Minister: How on earth can he now claim that the case has not been decided on its merits, and how can he explain his blatant undermining of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the Public Service dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member failed to mention the next sentence in the Commission's decision, which said that, against that history, it could not find that the case was special and isolated, and therefore it did not get up under the anomalies principle. That gets to the essence of the issue. What the Commission decided in that case was that this was not a special and isolated case, as it must be under the anomalies principle, because it was concerned, looking at the history of wage fixation in the Public Service area, that, every time there had been an increase in APS wages over the last decade or so, there had been a cycle of movements which had gone on in the rest of the public sector and the APS, although moved up against other groups, had then finished up back where it started. Against that history of movement, flow on and interaction, the Commission decided that this could not be seen as a special and isolated case.

ANSWER.PARA: What that indicates is that clearly what the Commission was motivated by in deciding that this case should be dismissed was a concern about flow on. It was not dealing with the merits of the case per se in a situation in which flow on would not exist. That gets to the absolute essence of the issue, and this will be the subject of debate after Question Time. I shall take up the matter further with the honourable member then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs assure the House that this Government will not intervene in the current independence struggle in New Caledonia by the deployment of Australian troops?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's question refers to commentary that took place in New Caledonia, mainly from the middle to the end of last month, along the lines that there was a belief that there was an elite force of 1,000 Australian military personnel trained, deployed, ready for movement to New Caledonia and military intervention. We inquired as to the cause of this report, which received fairly extensive publication, including in mainland France, and we discovered that on 14 January, on the radio program AM, I mentioned in passing that my Department had established a task force on the situation in New Caledonia. This had been freely interpreted in New Caledonia as force de frappe, which, of course, means a military strike force; hence, the rather feverish, hallucinatory commentary that developed.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has absolutely no military interest in intervening in any part of the region. We will do all we can to avoid conflict. We want to see the avoidance of bloodshed and tension. To the extent we can make contributions in that respect, we will do so. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. Is the Minister concerned about the milk blockades in Victoria and threatened blockades in the Australian Capital Territory and South Australia and the prospect of an interstate milk war? What does the Minister expect to achieve at the meeting of agriculture Ministers on Thursday of this week to end this crisis? Does the Minister agree that the blame for the current crisis in the dairy industry lies upon the shoulders of the Victorian Labor Government and to a lesser extent upon his own shoulders for having failed to achieve agreement on the modified national dairy plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I must say to the honourable gentleman is, of course, that the blockade is purely politically motivated by the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia because there is an election on. This action is a totally negative action. The demands by these Leongatha militants would cost the Commonwealth Government $190m per annum, and that is how absurd the requests are becoming. They also want another 6.6c per litre from the State Government, and that is a matter for the State Government. The Premier of Victoria, the Victorian Minister and the Victorian Government have been acting for and with the Victorian industry. The problem with the dairy industry of this country is that there are six dairy industries. Apart from the States, the honourable member for the Northern Territory has 300 cows and then there is the Australian Capital Territory. The problem is that one cannot get the States to agree, and that has gone on for about 50 years in the dairy industry.

ANSWER.PARA: No man has fought harder for his dairy industry than the Minister for Agriculture, Mr Kent, during the period of negotiation over the past year, because of the problems in the dairy industry. The reason he opposed the Australian Dairy Industry Conference plan was that the adjustment would fall most heavily on Victoria; the levy being proposed would not have given the Victorian dairy farmers enough money. That is simply because the Victorian dairy farmers produce about 57 to 60 per cent of Australia's milk.

The blockade is a purely political stunt. Of course, we ought to look at what the Victorian Leader of the Opposition has to say about these things. This is the fellow who blames the Victorian Government for the collapse of the Australian currency, and cats and dogs not being safe. That is about the level of his performance. I have here the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation pamphlet sent to its members. It tells of a meeting that took place on 13 February and states:

After the Premier of Victoria and the president of the ADFF had spoken to the meeting the Victorian Opposition Leader Mr J. Kennett, leapt uninvited onto the platform. For two or three minutes UDV President Bill Pyle and Kennett squabbled over the microphone, cheered on by an appreciative audience.
This is politics Liberal style. It continues:
Eventually Bill Pyle won the first round but not before Kennett alleged that Pyle or the UDV had 'done a (secret) deal' with the Victorian Government.
Kennett, with Tom Austin, Opposition Spokesman on Agriculture in tow, then left the hall only to return five minutes later.
Following a resolution from the meeting that he be heard, Mr Kennett told the audience that if elected his Government would:
1. Move milk interstate.
2. Deregulate market milk prices-
that would be just marvellous-
(does this mean Mr Kennett has 'done a deal' with the supermarkets for cheap milk?)
That is what is coming from the Liberal Opposition Leader in Victoria.

Of course, it was the Liberal Party in government in Victoria for so many years that kept on pushing up dairy production in that State. The Liberal Government pushed it up and pushed it up. The market for Australian milk is about 4.3 billion litres; the profitable market is about 4.6 billion litres. Today we are producing 5.9 billion litres, and that is the problem; too much supply and disastrous international prices, neither of which is controlled by this Government or any government particularly.

The militants are attacking the only profitable markets. They will achieve nothing if they attempt to blockade the Australian Capital Territory because the Territory will get milk from New South Wales. I imagine that if they blockade the South Australian and Victorian markets ways and means will be found to get around that as well. This is a purely politically motivated blockade. I notice that the Opposition is supporting this industrial action, as it supports the militant doctors. I have received a series of demands totalling around $190m. That is simply nonsense, particularly with the Liberal Party of Australia and other parties represented in this place talking about keeping the Budget deficit down. Let us reflect on the existing mechanism, which is covered by ongoing legislation. No agreement was reached in 1977; so we have the ridiculous situation of no producer producing prescribed products ever receiving the real price for his product and no manufacturer getting the real price, due to the complicated system of export pooling, equalisation, allowances and an export levy. This genius of a scheme, concocted by the previous Government back in 1977 because no agreement was reached, also has a system of domestic value for levy purposes, whereby three times a year the Commonwealth Government is supposed, acting under 10 criteria--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Some history is necessary to answer a question effectively but the Minister is going over the same story time and again. It ought to be drawn to a conclusion.

—Will the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations confirm that the community employment program has contributed to the successful attack on the level of unemployment in Victoria? Further, will his recent announcement of a further 622 jobs result in a further reduction in unemployment in Victoria, and has the rate at which persons are finding continuing employment after finishing a period of work on the CEP exceeded his expectations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that the CEP has made a very important contribution to employment growth, but it is by no means the only factor generating the strong employment growth occurring under this Government. In the course of our period in office employment has grown by just under 300,000 jobs and about 10 per cent of that growth can be attributed to the community employment program. Of course various jobs created in the early stages have now finished; so we do not have all of them on the go at present. Overall, some 60,000 jobs have been created under the CEP. As I say, some of those jobs would now have ended. So it has made a very important contribution, particularly given the fact that it has been aimed at those who are least likely to get a job in the context of economic recovery-the people who have been out of work for a long time and other disadvantaged people, such as Aborigines, non-English speaking migrants and women, who generally have much more difficulty getting jobs in the labour market than the rest of the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: The CEP has made a very important contribution to employment growth throughout the country, especially in Victoria. The CEP had as its predecessor there the job creation scheme initiated by the Victorian Government, the employment initiatives program, which was the forerunner of the wage pause program which came in before the community employment program. Victorians, therefore, have had a long experience of job creation programs under the Cain Government. In each of the three programs that have been run the Victorians have been able to achieve a substantial success. We have found from the employment initiatives program initiated by the Cain Government that there has been a great amount of success in terms of the people who have been through those jobs getting permanent jobs in the work force. Of course, the idea of the job creation program is to get these people a permanent job-not a permanent job in the sense of that particular job in the job creation program, but to get them out of unemployment, give them a chance to show that they can hold down a job, improve their employability in their own eyes and in the eyes of employers and, therefore, give them a much better chance of getting a job in the work force generally.

The Victorian Government is to be congratulated on recommencing in this country the concept of job creation which conservative governments had lampooned and forsaken. Its initiative was emulated in a sort of last gasp effort by the Fraser Government with the wage pause program, a hastily conceived program which has been greatly improved upon under the CEP. I am sure that everyone in this chamber recognises the enormous importance of job creation programs. I think we should thank the Victorian Government for setting the example in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House that the Government has decided that the next census of population and housing will be conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1986, in accordance with provisions of the Census and Statistics Act 1905. The date of the census will be 30 June 1986. At the conclusion of this statement I will table regulations specifying the topics to be included in the census and an explanatory statement. In order that the Parliament and the general public should be fully informed on the questions to be asked in the census, I will also table a paper entitled 'The 1986 Census of Population and Housing: Content and Procedures' which gives a description of the topics to be included, the proposed questions and the methods of conducting the census.

SPEECH.PARA: The census is the most wide-ranging collection undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Statistics as it involves contact with every household in the country. It provides a considerable amount of information used extensively by government bodies for policy formulation and monitoring. It provides a statistical profile of the whole population in terms of number, age and geographical distribution, and in terms of a range of demographic and social characteristics. Users include government agencies at the Federal, State and local level; welfare and social service organisations; research institutions; bodies undertaking regional; manpower and educational studies; demographies; business organisations and private individuals.

The Government has decided that the census will seek a total of 46 responses from households, which is a very small increase from the 43 responses required in 1981. The inclusion of many additional topics was requested by users, but the topics selected by the Government are considered to represent a reasonable balance between the need for information, the appropriateness of the census as a means of collecting particular kinds of data, the difficulty with some topics of formulating questions likely to get accurate and consistent answers, and the desire that completing the forms should not impose too great a task on the public. The conduct of the census will require the expenditure over the next four years of an additional $59m in current prices from the budgets of the Bureau of Statistics and associated service departments. The Government recognises that asking questions of householders in order to obtain statistical information involves a degree of intrusiveness and places a burden on the community. The Government has aimed to minimise both burden and intrusion but nevertheless accepts that some degree of each is a necessary requirement for the collection of statistical data. For the first time, the 1986 census will include questions on each person's ancestry and on language, other than English spoken at home. These questions will greatly improve census data collected on the ethnic composition of Australia's population and provide data for planning and evaluating services to migrants and ethnic communities.

A number of improvements to census data on families are planned for the 1986 census. Firstly, the inclusion of a question on usual residents temporarily absent will allow family members temporarily absent on census night to be included in the coding of family structures. This will overcome the problem created by absent spouses in previous censuses leading to overstatement of the number of single parent families and understatement of the number of families with both partners normally resident in a household. Secondly, a change in the question on relationships within a household will make it possible to produce statistics on de facto living arrangements and children in blended families. Thirdly, in response to many user requests, statistics will be produced for the first time on the family structure of persons residing in caravans or mobile homes in caravan parks.

At the request of educational authorities, an additional question for those attending an educational institution will enable comprehensive statistics to be produced on characteristics of people attending various types of institution.

A question on the material of the outer walls of dwellings has been included in previous censuses. This question is no longer considered to be a satisfactory indicator of housing conditions, and the Government has decided not to include it in the 1986 census. A number of other census questions have been simplified in order to reduce the number of responses required, without detracting from the data collected.

The 1986 census will be the first to include Australia's external territories. This will be different from past practice in which separate censuses have been conducted in each of Cocos (Keeling), Christmas and Norfolk Islands.

Public understanding and acceptance of the census is essential for statistics of a high quality to be produced. For this reason a substantial public awareness campaign will be conducted prior to the census. The aims will be to make known the availability of assistance for those who may, for language or other reasons, experience difficulty in completing the form, to explain the measures taken to ensure the confidentiality of the information provided and to explain the uses made of the statistics obtained from the Census.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to give them envelopes?

—A number of organisations and individuals have requested that information on identified persons and households not be destroyed, but be transferred in some form to archives, with access for most purposes forbidden for many years. The Government rejects this request.
—What about envelopes?

—The purpose of the census is to gather statistical information and the legal obligation on people to answer census questions, except one relating to religion, is accompanied by strict measures to ensure the confidentiality of the information provided. The Government believes that it would be inconsistent with that purpose and with that guarantee of confidentiality to retain information on identified persons or households; including envelopes. Consequently the present practice of destroying all records, including envelopes, of names and addresses and of not entering such names and addresses into the computer record will be continued.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government places great significance on the census as a means of collecting important social and economic data which is of primary concern to a wide range of users. It is recognised that, to be of maximum utility, such data must be both accurate and timely. Consequently, the Government has decided that all forms collected at the 1986 census will be processed fully and without delay so that detailed information is available to users as soon as possible. The Australian Statistics Advisory Council has given a considerable amount of time to considering plans for the 1986 census and its conclusions have been of great assistance to the Government in reaching its decisions.
I now table the following papers:
1986 Census of Population and Housing-Ministerial Statement, 25 February 1985.
The 1986 Census of Population and Housing: Content and Procedures.
Census Regulations.

That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I am not opening up a minefield for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) in raising discussion on this subject. On behalf of the Opposition, I welcome the statement and the outline of content and procedures of the 1986 census of population and housing. The Minister has revealed that the cost of undertaking the census is something of the order of $59m. That is a quite large amount of money. Honourable members need to know that the undertaking of this sort of enterprise is worthwhile. It is important that the Minister outline, as he has, the reasons for undertaking a census of this order and magnitude and some of the reasons for the information being required.

SPEECH.PARA: Requirements in a large number of Acts of Parliament depend upon population estimates being obtained on a regular basis. This is perhaps the most substantial and overriding reason for the fact that since 1961 the census has been carried out on a regular basis-that is, every five years-and why it is required again in 1986. These population estimates are required for the determination of the number of seats in the House of Representatives for each State, the allocation of funds for each State under the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 and the funding of local government authorities. While many of us might doubt the efficacy of some of the material produced from time to time by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, particularly in the area of national accounts and labour force statistics, in this instance the whole of the population is to be surveyed. So one certainly hopes that, for the large amount of money that is to be spent on undertaking this enterprise, we will have an accurate picture of the Australian population and that Government programs in so many areas, as outlined by the Minister, will be enhanced by having that information available.

I notice that in this census the Government, conscious of the need for public understanding of the necessity for the census, is to embark upon a substantial public awareness campaign prior to the census being undertaken. Having regard to the real concerns that exist in the community about the way in which information might be able to be used and the linking of it with other decisions of the Government-I have in mind in this instance the assets test in regard to which people have been concerned about the sort of information that might be obtained-I think there is very good and substantial reason for ensuring that people are aware of the way in which this census is to be handled.

The Minister has mentioned the intrusiveness that some people feel is involved when a census is undertaken. The number of questions, of course, is important in judging the extent to which people might feel that a census is intrusive. The Minister recounts in his address that some 43 responses from households were required in 1981. He tells us now that a total of 46 responses is to be required. He might care at a later time to clarify for me why the discussion paper itself refers to 48 responses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two are subsidiaries to other major questions.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. It is, of course, the extent to which information is sought that many people feel is intrusive. For that reason I believe that it is important that the Minister ensures that the public is aware of the need for the census. However, I hasten to caution that there is a very considerable cynicism about public relations campaigns, particularly in New South Wales, and the way they have been used. The amount of money of the total allocated for ensuring public awareness is a matter one might critically review. However, I believe that the most important statements are contained at the end of the document. They concern the request that census information be made more generally available and particularly that the original information taken from the people interviewed be kept as part of our archival record. I think there would have been very real concern were that information to have been retained. I am sure that I speak on behalf of members of the Opposition when I welcome the Government's decision to ensure that when the statistical information is collected-including the names and addresses-it is destroyed immediately after the information is entered in the computer record and the confirmation that the names and addresses from which the information is to be obtained will not form part of the computer record. That was a very important and welcome decision.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the interjection earlier of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), a section of the booklet he will no doubt receive indicates very clearly that it is the intention in this census to ensure that an envelope is made available for the people who are unduly concerned about privacy, who perhaps may be concerned that the person who carries out the interview might be known to the interviewee or might remember information. An envelope will be provided in which information can be placed and given, sealed, to the collector. The envelope is not to be opened by the collector but is passed on to the group leader who will later check it for completeness and initiate any other action that might be required as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the envelope will be destroyed, too.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The extraordinary conduct of the Government in its handling of the Public Service dispute.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw attention to a matter of vital public importance. It is a matter which has caused Australia's economy to suffer in strategically important ways, which has caused massive disruption in the private sector to employers and employees who have been completely innocent of any involvement in this debacle, and which has caused a loss of confidence in the Government's ability to handle its own industrial relations responsibilities, a loss of confidence which, I submit, is so total that the Government is unlikely to ever recover its credibility. I speak about the Government's extraordinary conduct, in fact the Government's appalling mismanagement, of the Commonwealth Public Service dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government have betrayed the Australian people on security matters, and they have, they have certainly also betrayed the Australian people in respect of responsibility for industrial relations matters in their handling of the Public Service dispute. For five weeks this Government presided over Public Service industrial action which severely affected productive business, small business in particular, and Australian taxpayers at large. The unwillingness of this Government to debate that matter last week is indicative of its embarrassment.

The damage that has resulted from the Government's ineptness, its weakness in this dispute, cannot be understated. The evidence abounds-a sinking dollar, capital markets flooded with money that should be in the Commonwealth Treasury, wharves choked with goods, and workers everywhere in the private sector wondering whether they might be, or whether they could have been, stood down because of the Government's chronic inaction. This situation was allowed to fester for five weeks. An amount of $900m in government revenue was held up in January alone as a result of Public Service union bans, at a cost of $18m in interest charges to Australian taxpayers. One might as well double those figures if one takes into account the month of February as well. Who knows what further cost is yet to come? The dispute is not yet over. The Government is not yet out of the woods. Of course, everybody is breathing a sigh of relief at the temporary truce, but no one has mistaken it for a real and lasting solution.

For five weeks the Government was impotent. For three of those weeks the Government stood before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and said: 'Please, may we have the power to stand down striking public servants who are sabotaging our vital government revenue and collection services'? Why did the Government have to do this? Why did it have to waste three of those weeks, standing in front of the Commission saying 'Please' in respect of its own employees? The Government did so because it had repealed a reasonable piece of legislation, which was introduced, passed and proclaimed by the former coalition Government and which was a valuable and effective tool of deterrence-the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act. The Government is having trouble not only with nuclear deterrence; it is having trouble with industrial relations deterrence as well.

Why did the Government repeal the CE (EP) Act in the first place? It did so because that was what the Public Service unions wanted. That was the price the the Government was willing to pay for the prices and incomes accord and for substantial donations to Australian Labor Party coffers from Public Service unions. That is the sort of Government we have, one which is totally beholden-beholden to Caucus on matters of national security and beholden to the Public Service in respect of government activity. This is supposedly the special relationship that this Government has with the trade union movement, a special relationship that puts union interests ahead of Australian taxpayers' interests.

Because the Government repealed the CE (EP) legislation, sections of our economy were plunged into chaos and we had the incredible situation where, in effect, militant Public Service unionists were denying an elected government Supply. That is the incredible situation that we witnessed during those five weeks. While Public Service unionists were refusing to work as directed, while they gathered around safes, while they hid cheques to prevent loyal public servants from getting access to Commonwealth money, the Government went cap in hand to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and said: 'Please, may we chastise our errant public servants?' When at long last the Government received temporary stand-down provisions, just over 100 public servants Australia-wide were subject to those provisions.

In January alone the cost to Australian taxpayers was $18m resulting from this Government's inaction. But what is the total cost throughout the community during those months and what is to be the total cost to the community before this dispute is finally resolved-$30m, $40m, $50m? Who knows? What sort of government is it that relinquishes reasonable Commonwealth powers at the behest of unions and then gets caught with its pants down, absolutely powerless, by those very same unions during an industrial dispute? It is not only an ineffectual, weak and incompetent government, but it is a very stupid and naive government.

It is not surprising in a government of this calibre that we find the responsible Minister supporting a wage increase absolutely and completely outside the bounds of the Government's own wage fixing guidelines. For the benefit of honourable members, I quote from that sacred document, the so-called accord:
Both parties recognise that if the essential conditions of the centralised system are met there shall be no extra claims except where special and extraordinary circumstances exist.
Let me now quote from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decision of 10 January 1985, when it threw completely out of court the spurious case of the Public Service:

We have come to the conclusion that the history of the market relied on by the applicants does not support the claims. Against that history we reject the submissions that the circumstances in which the claims were brought are of a special and isolated nature. We hold that there is no anomaly requiring rectification.

The Minister will note that I have quoted in full the conclusion of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission judgment. If he reads it on its merits he will note that the beginning of that conclusion dealt with the merits of the case, and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission said:
We have come to the conclusion that the history of the market relied on by the applicants does not support the claims.

Finally, he will note that in the last sentence of that judgment it dealt with the flow-on consequences of the case. It is spurious for the Minister to argue that it dealt with only flow-ons, because it did not; it dealt with both the merits of the case and the flow-on consequences.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission made a clear and unequivocal decision in this case. It delivered a sweeping dismissal. Yet we now find the Government whimpering back to the Commission in the face of union action and pressure, breaking its own wage fixation principles with a 2 per cent across the board offer, in order to seek a politically expedient solution to the dispute, to get the Government off the hook.

The Minister is leaning on the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and he knows it. He is prepared to lean on the Commission, to undermine its decisions, in order to get him and the Government out of trouble on this issue. His statement that the Commission's concerns about flow-ons prevented an examination of the merits of the case is false. One only has to look at the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of 20 February, if the Minister is not prepared to read the decision of 10 January properly, where it says:
However, we are constrained to say that on our reading of the decision, contrary to Mr Kelty's submission-
that is, Mr Kelty's submission for the Australian Council of Trade Unions-

the Public Service Full Bench did consider in detail the problem which '. . . arises from the interaction of wage and salary rates within the public sectors Federal and State and between the public and private sectors'.
The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission examined both the merits of the case and, indeed, the flow-on consequences. The Commission found:

At almost every point of comparison of minimum salaries within the clerical and administrative structure, that is, at both the base and above base levels, the survey results for the private sector are markedly less than those for the public sector.

The Commission unequivocally rejected the Public Service unions' goal of the fixation of rates in close proximity to the Victorian public sector rates and ahead of all other public sector rates, noting that to rule in its favour would place public servants in a pace-setting position once again, breaching the position taken by the Government in the communique of the National Economic Summit Conference, that is:

Governments have a responsibility to their own employees and consequently accept that their overall wages and conditions should be commensurate with recognised general standards while they should not be used as pace-setters.

The Public Service unions argued for the setting of salaries ahead of those for comparable work in the private sector and ahead of those enjoyed by all public servants in every State except Victoria. The Commission clearly rejected their case on its merits. It is a nonsense for the Minister now to argue, and write letters to the Sydney Morning Herald as he did, saying that it was otherwise. The reality is that the Government is now pursuing a politically expedient course, which involves undermining the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in order to get it off the hook in this dispute.

It is true that the Commission was concerned about flow ons; I have never denied that. That is to be found in its 10 January decision. I also am concerned about flow ons, as indeed the Minister is and should be. The possibility of another damaging wage round flowing from any wage rise over and above that awarded in the national wage case is all too real. A non-CPI linked rise for public servants would be a signal to all and sundry that the Government is weak, that it can be leant on and that it will go to the Commission and seek exemption after exemption from its own wage fixing guidelines, for this union and for that union, until wage restraint under our present centralised system is a dead letter. If that is to happen-because it is one of the consequences of this Government's response to the Public Service wage claim-indeed the Government's own beloved centralised wage fixing principles will be lying in tatters around its feet.

The Minister must realise that the Government cannot have its cake and eat it too. The Government cannot support a centralised wage fixation system and then, in the face of an umpire's decision that one of the supplicants to the Commission does not agree with, turn around behind the Commission's back and seek to bring in under some exemption or another, under some reading or another which suits the Minister's own purposes, grounds for a rehearing of this case. If the Minister is about to embark on that dangerous political course he must realise that staring him squarely in the face is the death of the present centralised wage fixation system and wage restraint, of which he and his Government are so proud.

It is pathetic and most contemptible that the Minister should attempt to mislead the public about the Commission's position in this case. The Commission did consider the Public Service case on its merits; any other reading of that judgment that comes to any other conclusion is simply self-serving for political interests. It considered both merits and flow-ons. It has made a courageous decision in the face of the Public Service application, and the Minister is embarking indeed on a very dangerous course if he now continues with the action proposed.

What should have been said by the Government to the Public Service unions is that they should go away and reconsider the entire question of public sector remuneration in the context of the August-September consideration of the wage fixation principles themselves. The Government, if it continues with this course, faces no alternative-there can be no other conclusion -to realising that it is heralding a wage round outside indexation which is going to have very severe employment consequences indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government totally refutes the charges that have been made and the many epithets that have been thrown at me by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). The fact is that he is engaging in massive misrepresentation of the Government's position and showing a gross misunderstanding of the circumstances in which this dispute is being conducted and even about the way in which this claim comes forward. It is pointless and stupid to quote the no extra claims provision as though any claim apart from that is outside the principles. The honourable member for Tangney apparently does not even know that this wage claim was brought within the principles. One can argue about the amount of the claim-indeed, about whether any amount should have been brought-but one cannot argue that it has not been properly brought under the anomalies principles. There is a right under the principles for people to bring claims for an equitable base, on the basis that there is not at the start of the indexation system an equitable base. That was built into the system, and claims based on that are not outside the guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Tangney shows a gross ignorance of the whole wage principles if he does not understand that point. He says that any increase that would flow on that basis would be outside the principles and would destroy the wage fixation and the wage indexation systems. That is absolute, total nonsense. The fact is that this Government has strongly defended the national wage principles in everything it has done since the principles were adopted. The Government has not at any time had any intention to destroy those principles, nor indeed to undermine the Commission, as was alleged many times by the honourable member for Tangney.

Of course we support the national wage principles. We were instrumental in getting them adopted, in that we strongly argued to the Commission that it should introduce those wage principles. Indeed, we supported them fully. It has also been part of our purpose in addressing this dispute to do justice to the Public Service anomalies claims. I said that it is properly brought under the principles, but it has also been our purpose in addressing that claim to ensure that the claim did not result in a wage increase which would create problems. It has also been our purpose to do all in our power to protect the public interest from the damaging effects of any industrial action which was taken in respect of this claim, such as the action which was begun in January.

That has been the course on which we have embarked and, in accordance with that approach, we supported an increase of 2 per cent because we believed that such an increase was all that was justified. That is much less than the 8.3 per cent claimed. We believed that there was a case for some small increase. It is a fact that Commonwealth public servants are paid less than any State public servants and that they are near the bottom of the public sector market. On the available evidence, they are also a little behind the private sector market. However, it seemed to us that an increase of 2 per cent properly addressed the situation in respect of trying to find a balance in the overall market, public and private. We in no way believe that in supporting that 2 per cent increase we are doing anything to undermine the national wage principles. On the contrary, we are ensuring the strength of those principles by providing an equitable base upon which everyone could be satisfied with indexation.

When the claim was rejected by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and union bans were imposed, we immediately informed the unions that stand-down action would be taken. I said that on the same day as the bans were announced. We also said that the bans would have no influence on the Government. We said that there would be no deals outside the Arbitration Commission, and there have not been and will not be any deals outside the Commission. To enter into such deals obviously would be an open invitation to employers and unions everywhere to negotiate outside the Commission and so destroy the wage fixing principles. From the very outset we have made it clear to the Public Service unions that, whatever their bans, they would have no effect on the Government in terms of getting the Government to agree to anything outside the Commission; that no deals would be done outside the Commission and any redress would have to come from within the Commission. We said that the bans were pointless and the unions had only themselves to blame for the dismissal of the case because they did not address seriously the flow-on issue-a factor which we addressed with great concern before the Commission-and that the unions' only further recourse, if any, was to address the flow-on issue seriously and try to get some guarantees so they could go back to the Commission and seek a re-opening of the case.

Why was a re-opening of the case possible? In our view it was possible because the decision dismissed the claim because of concern over consequential claims, based on the previous history of Australian Public Service pay rises. The honourable member for Tangney has referred to the decision. Let me say to him that I do not agree with his interpretation of the words he read to the House. I go back to them. The Commission looked at the ranking schedule of some 26 employing areas-public and private but mostly public-which had been used in Public Service pay cases since 1966. It said: 'Looking at that, we do not accept that the Public Service has a right to be at any particular level of that schedule, as the unions argued'. Neither does the Government, and that is what we argued in the case. The Commission said: 'History shows that following public sector pay increases we get movement, a series of consequential claims and increases, and the Australian public servants finish back where they started'. It said that movement and not stability was the norm. We agree with that. Then, at the end of page 16 of the decision, it said:

We have come to the conclusion that the history of the market relied on by the applicants does not support the claims. Against that history we reject the submissions that the circumstances in which the claims were brought are of a special and isolated nature.

The Commission was saying that, if we look at history, we will see that when there is an increase there are consequential moves; therefore, in the circumstances of an equitable base claim, which under the principles has to be special and isolated-we cannot say that this is a special and isolated claim because, based on the history of wage fixation in this area, there will be consequential movements which breach the principle-the Commission cannot find that there is a rectifiable anomaly. The Commission went on to say:
We hold that there is no anomaly requiring rectification.
Our finding makes it unnecessary to consider the other issues which were debated during the proceedings.
Of course a whole lot of other issues were debated during the proceedings. The honourable member for Bradfield sits wobbling his head as though he has achieved something.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are agreeing with me.

—I am not agreeing at all; I am saying the unions have not addressed the merits of the issue and that a whole lot of issues apart from flow-ons are involved in addressing the matter of an equitable base. If the flow-on issue is put to one side and stabilised so there are no flow-ons, the establishment of an equitable base on the basis of deciding in the face of the market where is the appropriate level for the Australian Public Service can be undertaken. There would be a rectifiable anomaly in those circumstances because it would be special and isolated. That is the whole point of our argument, the whole point in saying that there is a case to take back to the Commission on those grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an extremely important part of the Opposition's case. Members of the Opposition say, having read too much of the Sydney Morning Herald, that the merits have been addressed and that the Commission has dismissed the issue on that basis. Obviously it has not. Therefore this case is capable of being re-opened. Once the flow-on issue has been addressed and set aside-assuming that can be done; it is by no means certain at this stage-it will be possible to analyse the matter on its merits.

The Commission has said that it supports the Government's decision. After listening to the honourable member for Tangney saying that we are undermining the Commission, one would think that the Commission opposed what we were doing. The fact is that the Commission has supported what the Government is saying in the sense that it has said 'Yes, this case can be re-opened'. It has looked at the same evidence as the honourable member for Tangney, the Opposition and the Sydney Morning Herald and said that this matter can be re-opened. It said it could be re-opened because of the way in which the decision was made on 10 January. The fact is that the re-opening will not be an appeal; it will be a further hearing of an issue based on other material which will seek to overcome the basis on which the original decision was made; that is, to assure the Commission that there will not be a flow-on. Such an assurance would enable a hearing on the merits of the matter. That is the kind of issue we have before us. When the Commission addressed this issue following a request from the Australian Council of Trade Unions during the national wage case last week, it said:

On the material before us we do not regard a relisting of the matter as being inconsistent with either the traditional practice of the Commission or the current Principles . . . Nor should such relisting be seen as being at variance with the decision of the Public Service Full Bench. Indeed, this decision was accepted as correct by all those who made submissions on the ACTU's application and its correctness was not challenged by the ACTU. It is on that basis that any further hearing must proceed.

The Commission is saying that this is not some appeal against that decision; it is a further hearing starting from the point at which everyone accepts that the decision was right in the sense that it dismissed the claim because of this flow-on problem but, if arguments can be found which set that concern aside, the matter can be considered on its merits. That is what the Bench was saying in its decision in the national wage case last week. That totally confounds the argument of the Opposition, which would have the country believe we are doing something to undermine or destroy totally the Arbitration Commission. The Commission is agreeing with the Government on this issue; it says the matter can be re-opened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you have stood over them.

—It is absurd to say we have stood over the Commission, and the honourable member knows it. This case is one in which the Government supported the ACTU application for a re-opening, with provisos. We said we would support a re-opening only if the bans were lifted and if satisfactory flow-on guarantees were obtained. Of course, that is the hurdle that has to be overcome. The ACTU is seeking to get evidence to that effect. If it can do so, perhaps it can provide a basis on which an increase can be granted, if the Commission deems that appropriate. It certainly will not be able to do that unless it can get some sort of guarantee and overcome the concerns rightly and properly expressed by the Commission in its decision to dismiss this claim. It is also absurd to describe this as a victory for union militancy, as some have. This is not a victory for union militancy because the course I have suggested was open to the unions from day one. They could have taken that course without undertaking any of these stupid bans, which have just created an enormous amount of trouble for the nation without in any way enhancing the case of the Public Service unions, without changing the Government's mind in any way. Certainly they cannot be seen logically by anyone as a victory for union militancy.

SPEECH.PARA: As I stated earlier, we told the unions at the outset that the bans would have no effect on the Government's position and they have not. We have gone through the stand-down procedure. We said that there would be stand-downs if they went ahead with the bans. Those stand-downs occurred; 363 people were stood down and of those 363, approximately 100 had come back to work by the time the bans were lifted. We sought the right to stand down people through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is true that that did take a little time. It did not take three weeks as the honourable member for Tangney said because, from the time that the bans were announced, there was quite some time before they were effectively implemented and before they were starting to have any effect. So it was not until that time that we were able to go to the Commission. We would not have been able to apply any stand-downs, even with management initiated 'no work as directed, no pay' provisions, until the bans were actually having some effect. We were able to go to the Commission, obtain those powers and stand down several hundred people.

The effectiveness of the stand-down orders was reasonably substantial. We were able to get the money flowing again through the taxation area. We did have problems in the Customs area that related to standing down people who have a discretion as to how they work and as to what goods need investigation. They suddenly decided that all goods needed investigation and that created a problem in applying stand-down orders which we overcame in the last few days of the bans being applied.

The Opposition claims that if the Government had not repealed the management initiated 'no work as directed, no pay' provisions under the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act, it could have prevented industrial action much more effectively. We completely and utterly reject the suggestion that repeal of these measures was ill advised. They were provocative, confrontationist, authoritarian measures typical of the Fraser Government which we will not have a bar of. They provided the Commonwealth with rights to stand down far in excess of those applying to private employers who have to go to the Commission to get these rights. There was no right of appeal. They prevented the Commission making awards to give such rights and the CE(EP) Act had even been condemned by the International Labour Organisation's Freedom of Association Committee for those reasons.

The granting of powers by the Commission was delayed somewhat by legal argument but the Commission has now declared that there is a right for the Commonwealth to get these powers and that legal argument will not hold water in the future. Problems in the Customs area would have occurred with or without management initiated retirement and we will overcome those in the future. Nevertheless, we will be analysing the processes to ensure that we are able more effectively to deal with this in the future, particularly bearing in mind that this was the first time stand downs had been sought since the Public Service Arbitrator's jurisdiction had been abolished and everything brought under the Commission. There were some initial problems which will not be there on a subsequent occasion. The Government believes that its actions, far from being extraordinary, are totally satisfactory in the circumstances.
