SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On hearing the alleged defence of the Government's actions in relation to the Public Service dispute it becomes quite clear that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) failed to read on the blue business sheet the exact terminology of this matter of public importance. For his benefit I read it into the record. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The extraordinary conduct of the Government in its handling of the Public Service dispute.

This subject can probably be best subdivided into two quite distinct sections: Firstly, the Government's handling of the dispute before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; and, secondly, the Government's handling of the industrial disputation which resulted from it.

I hope that the Minister is aware of the fact that, prior to the Public Service dispute, the Government made its position quite clear when it accepted the national wage decision of 23 December 1983 that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should introduce a system of wage indexation. It set down eleven principles which were also accepted by the majority of unions, including the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and the Australian Public Service Association. In proceedings before the Academic Salaries Tribunal, however, the Government submitted:
. . . the metal industries standard is the basis for adjustments to establishing an equitable basis for pay rate awards.

It must be noted, therefore, that the metal industries standard has been sacrosanct for many years in Australian industrial relations as a basis for basic wage adjustments and national wage cases. The metal industries standard was qualified in this case by the Commonwealth in the medical officers case when it set a figure of 15.17 per cent. In the same case, the Australian Council of Trade Unions set the figure at 14.2 per cent. On that occasion the Government argued that, if the total post-indexation increase exceeded the metal industry standard regardless of the basis on which increases were made, no equitable base for any increase would be justified. It should be remembered that the total base indexation salary movement for the ACOA and the APSA was approximately 16 per cent at the base grade with more for higher grades. Therefore, if the Government intended to remain consistent with its earlier case, it should have refused to support before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission any increase for the ACOA and APSA members on an across the board basis.

The Government's attitude towards salary increases in the public sector has always been ambivalent. When addressing the National Council of the ACOA on 4 March 1984 the then Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) said:
When comparing the position of Commonwealth public servants to other public servants, it is extremely unfair to Commonwealth public servants.

He was referring to the position of base grade clerical staff but is it any wonder that the unions at that time took it as a nod and a wink from the Government that they would be able to go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with an across the board claim of 8.3 per cent? It is quite clear, therefore, that at the base of this entire argument is the fact that at the first election of the Hawke Government, and since then, this Government has claimed that it has a special relationship with the trade union movement-a relationship it has also claimed to have with both the ACOA and the APSA. What has been demonstrated in recent weeks, however, is that there is no special relationship whatsoever. The dangers of the Government's actions in this field were emphasised by the Australian Financial Review on 13 May last year. It stated:

For Mr Willis, the problem is that any wage increase for the Public Service, which of all the sections of the workforce is the one most directly under the Government's control, would inevitably be the occasion for a new discontent and flow-on demands from other unions.

That was a clear and unequivocal warning to the Minister in May 1983. The case before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and its decision was perfectly clear-cut. The Government was simply facing the situation of how to get out of a very difficult position. On the one hand, it had encouraged the unions to expect a wage increase and, on the other hand, it was facing very significant difficulties in supporting the principle of the accord and maintaining relationships with its employees.

The Minister has claimed that the Fraser Government legislation which he rejected, 'would be an important step in improving industrial relations in the public sector'. He said that in this House on 20 October 1983. We have now seen what it means because this Minister, above all people in the Government, is well aware of the fact that it takes two sides to reach a settlement. Quite clearly, the unions in this case were determined to go against the decision of the arbitrator and decided, therefore, that industrial disruption was the only solution to their problem.

This union dispute was created at a time when the unions said publicly that their objective was to smash the very essence of the Budget which this Parliament formulated. Yet the Minister claims a special relationship with the trade union movement. Is that why the Government took away the only effective teeth in the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act and the 'no work as directed, no pay' provision put in place by the previous Government specifically to give Governments the ability at a time such as this when Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decisions are not accepted by the unions as in this case? I was intrigued when I read the statement made by the Minister on 23 October 1983 in this House. He said:

This Government rejects such a confrontationist approach towards its own employees. The existence of legislation of this kind has acted against the development of improved industrial relations in the Commonwealth sector. Rather than encouraging a sound working relationship, such punitive legislation and action has actually led to a marked deterioration in employer-employee relations.
He went on to say:
. . . legislation enacted by the previous Government would not create a more rational industrial relations atmosphere in the public sector.

Very few people in Australia today believe that relations, in the public sector in particular, are in any sense rational. I quote from the bete noire of the Minister, the Sydney Morning Herald, dated 9 February this year. It stated:

Up to the end of office hours yesterday, only one person in Sydney, a manager in the cashier's department of the Taxation Office, had been stood down, although many of his colleagues are understood to have escaped by being hard to find when the stand-down orders were being handed out.

We had another interesting case in Perth where senior officers tried to collect funds from a safe but it was surrounded by clerical officers who refused to move. I ask the Minister: Was any attempt made to stand down the people who refused to move, who refused to prevent their senior officers from carrying out their lawful duties? We did not hear a word about that. The simple fact of the matter is that the Government has set a situation in place now where it is no longer respected. It lacks the discipline to carry out its own policies in relation to its own employees. Yet the Minister comes into this chamber and attempts, in a very ham-fisted manner indeed, to try to explain that in fact what the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission said was not contrary to government policy. I ask the Minister this clear question: Why have you supported even a 2 per cent across the board flow on? If there is a case for a change in structure at the lower clerical grades-if that can be demonstrated before the Commission, and to date it has not-I would suggest that the Minister has, as I said earlier, simply encouraged the unions to believe that an across the board salary increase was a very real probability.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in its judgment, made the other important point that it was very worried about a flow on; it was very worried about the leap-frogging effect of any determination which would give an increase. It is worth noting that a few days ago ACOA asked various unions to make public statements supporting the ACOA and APSA claims. For the benefit of this House, the important point which must be remembered is this: Not one word from any of those unions suggested that they rejected any increase as the basis of a flow on through the State conciliation and arbitration commissions. The historical evidence is clear-it was referred to the determination made by the Commission-that time after time, whenever there is an increase in the relativities between Federal Public Service salaries and those of State public servants, inevitably we see the flow on through to the State Public Service and the private sector, with the result that relativities are ultimately restored.

My colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) has made the point that in a few months time we will see this Government attempting to renegotiate the accord. I wish it well. That is all I can say on the basis of what it has done in this particular case. But, surely, it was in that context that the Public Service unions should have been renegotiating this case with particular emphasis on those clerical grades at the bottom who, as I said, may have a case. But I think it is a horrendous situation when we have a government of this country that aids and abets its own employees into expecting salary increases across the board when it has no basis in fact to grant those increases and when in fact it has gone against the determination of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which is, above all, the arbiter for fixing wage determinations in this country. If the Government is not going to support the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, all we can expect in the future is a considerable degree of industrial difficulties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an ex-school teacher, my colleagues will forgive me if I make some assessment of the speech just made by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). It was in the terms of a lecture to a classroom. Over the last 10 minutes we have heard a lecture delivered to this House on industrial relations. I rate the presentation of the honourable member for Bradfield reasonably highly. For presentation I give him at least five out of 10, but I am afraid on content I give him nought out of 10. The honourable member for Bradfield has failed to understand the position that the Government has taken consistently during this dispute. Members of the Government have not condoned the action taken by the Public Service in this dispute, and certainly have not done so by way of a public statement. What we have done is continually urge the Public Service unions to go back to arbitration. In a moment I want to go through the steps that we have taken in this dispute to show that, indeed, our handling of this issue is not extraordinary at all; it is very ordinary. In fact, we have fitted in totally with the industrial relations principles that we have consistently espoused since we came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) blamed the union dispute for everything, including the devaluation of the dollar. I thought that, though this House obviously welcomes his renewed presence, he might find his time more usefully spent going to the United Kingdom to advise Mrs Thatcher on how to deal with the devaluation of the pound. I am sure that the same sorts of solutions will not be able to be put into effect in the United Kingdom. As I listened to the speeches from those two members of the Opposition I was interested to hear what solutions they would put up to solve the industrial dispute that this country has had to deal with over the last few weeks. We heard nothing new at all. Despite the fact that the honourable member for Tangney has been absent from this House during a period of opposition, he has come back with no new ideas. What solution would members of the Opposition apply to this dispute? Exactly the same as when they were in government. They would reinstate all the previous industrial relations legislation, such as the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act and put that into effect. They think that would resolve the industrial dispute. I, and this Government, do not believe that jack-boot industrial relations is a sensible approach. This Government has the achievements on the books in the field of industrial relations.

Let me remind the House of the levels of industrial disputation over the years. Honourable members will see that with the approach the previous Government had and that the now Opposition still has, it did not stop industrial disputations; in fact, it added to them. For example, in 1981, 4.2 million working days were lost; in 1982, 2.2 million working days were lost; in 1983, 1.6 million working days were lost and in 1984 1.4 million working days were lost. The number of working days lost in 1984 was one-third of the 1981 figure. What is the policy of members of the Opposition on industrial relations? As I have said today, all we have heard is a recital of the views of the previous Government, the Fraser Government, about industrial relations. A new view has been put up by members of the back bench in dealing with the doctors dispute in New South Wales. There we have a case of right wing militants-as they are called by one of their own colleagues-withdrawing their services to the public with the Government, the community and their own peers asking them to return to work so that there can be sensible negotiations. What do members of the Opposition do? They condone that sort of action. If honourable members follow that to its logical conclusion, we will have industrial anarchy in this country.

I cannot understand the position of members of the Opposition in their handling of industrial disputes at all. On the one hand they say: 'If they are Commonwealth employees, you hit them over the head and blame them for everything, including the devaluation of the dollar. However, if they belong to the private sector and if they are professionals, you handle them in a totally different way-you let them do whatever they like and you condone it'. If that is the alternative that members of the Opposition have to offer this country in terms of industrial relations, thank God that they did not get elected in the last election. They never will if they follow those sorts of policies.

Members of the Opposition have accused the Government of extraordinary or unusual conduct in its handling of the Public Service pay dispute. Let me take the Opposition step by step through the role the Government took through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). Firstly, a claim of an anomaly was first lodged by the public sector unions in December 1983. Secondly, at the initial hearing the Government supported the funding of an arguable case and co-operated with the unions by an agreement that the Public Service Board conduct the market survey of comparative wage rates. Thirdly, at the substantive hearing the Government supported the 2 per cent increase provided that the Commission was satisfied that the key provision of the anomalies provision, that anomaly increases be special and isolated and not give rise to general wage movements, was satisfied. The Commission was not satisfied that there would not be significant pressures for further wage increases as a result of any increased award, and, therefore, rejected the claim.

So, in all this, the role of the Government has been to assist the unions with a survey of comparative wage rates, followed by supporting the principle for a 2 per cent increase provided key provisions of the anomalies principle are satisfied. Following intense industrial action by the unions involved, the Government applied to the Commission for the insertion of stand-down clauses in the relevant awards. The Commission accepted these applications. Late last week, as a result of an offer of resolution by this Government, industrial bans were lifted following agreement by unions to allow their revised anomaly pay claim to be reheard by a full bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

What is so extraordinary about that simple process? At no stage has the Government condoned the unions imposing bans. In fact the Government took action through appropriate channels to ensure that stand-down clauses were inserted in the award. That is not extraordinary at all. I suspect the real motivation behind raising this matter of public importance today has been simply to ensure that the Public Service bashers, who are alive and well on the Opposition benches, are able to have a voice. The Opposition has raised this issue today not because it was so called, 'extraordinary' but just because it wanted to continue the theme that it pushed consistently when in government.

What we see today are two alternatives. On the one hand, we see from the Opposition an approach to industrial relations which says: 'Get out the jack boots. Hit them hard. Sack them all. Don't listen to the wage claims at all, just apply the old harsh tactics in industrial relations that were offered to the community by the Fraser Government'. On the other hand, we have seen presented by the Government a sane, sensible approach which has been consistent over the whole of this industrial dispute. The Government said: 'Go back to the proper channels. Ask for a hearing, but lift your bans'. It is unfortunate that we had to impose stand-down clauses, but what was the alternative? The Opposition wants the CE(EP) Act to be reinstated in legislation so that it can be sure that public servants do not have the same rights as people employed in the private sector. To top off all that, members on the Opposition benches say: 'There are two standards. It does not matter about public servants. They should go back to work but not the people in the medical profession'. The medical profession's position is endorsed by members of the Opposition. If one follows that procedure and the philosophy of the Oppositions in terms of its industrial relations policy we will see industrial anarchy in this country. I think the Government should be congratulated on its handling of this dispute. It is unfortunate-

I will say a few words about the proposed change to the Sessional Orders and draw to the attention of the House the proposal which will come before it later in the week for the establishment of a procedures committee. It is very difficult to talk about the Sessional Orders as we are at the moment without drawing to the attention of honourable members that we are asking a joint committee to look at the procedures of this House, which may have some bearing on the decision which the Government has made today. That decision makes some minor alterations to the Sessional Orders in relation to the operation of this House. Hopefully the procedures committee will not see itself as a committee which must report back here in two or three years' time. However, there are some rather urgent matters which can be placed before it immediately and upon which the Government feels it could report to us expeditiously.

We have had a major influx of new honourable members to the House. A lot of them will be amazed at the somewhat archaic traditional procedures that we continue to live with, particularly in this chamber, the procedures with which we are more acquainted than perhaps we are with those of the other place. We have to try to establish a balance between the importance of this institution-the Parliament-and the responsibility and work of the Executive and the time it must have available to it to carry out the duties and responsibilities which are thrust upon its shoulders.

The timetable of the sitting hours of the Parliament has not changed much over the years. We have experimented with the sitting hours, as did the previous Government, and have made some slight alterations. The major change that took place last year was from a three-day sitting week, sitting three weeks and having a week off, to a four-day sitting week, sitting two weeks and having two weeks in the electorate. That move certainly has been applauded by members on this side of the House. Most honourable members seem to agree that this change gives them a better opportunity to do their work outside meeting their commitments in the Parliament. That is the system with which they want to continue and that is the system with which the Government has persevered in this motion today. Nevertheless, it was a major change. I know that at the end of the two weeks' sitting one is very tired. It is very exacting for members to be here eight working days straight. It means that a lot of honourable members who come from far distant areas-the north of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory-have, on some occasions, stayed in Canberra over the weekend rather than make the long journey back to their electorates, which they did every weekend when we were sitting three consecutive weeks. It does, of course, change the pattern and obviously adds to the responsibility of finding time for Cabinet, Cabinet sub-committees and the work of the Executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forget the Cabinet; think about the Parliament.
—The honourable member might forget about the Cabinet because it looks as though he has missed the bus, but to a lot of other people-
—Don't worry about that; he will be all right. You are on your last term.

—The honourable member for Denison says that we are on our last term. Irrespective of whether we are on our last term, I am now talking about the proper utilisation of time for all members-148 of them-and those people who are elected to carry out their responsibilities as Ministers. In addition there is the work of the Executive and the relationship it has with the Parliament. People should not underestimate that. I think we tend to do so before we serve in the Ministry. However, people who have had the experience of working in the Ministry will know that Ministers come into the chamber at the same time as delegations are waiting on them in their offices and they cannot tell the delegations at what time they will be able to see them. There are crucial matters to be discussed with people who visit the Parliament. Perhaps this has become a little more of a problem with the four-day sitting week than it was with the three-day sitting week. I think that is also a measure which ought to be studied by the procedures committee when it meets. I am sure back bench members will have some views that they wish to express about the matter. Some people have told me that they would prefer to go back to the old system of a three-day sitting week, but the majority seem to favour the change that was made last year, by which we are sticking.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I make is that the procedures which have been put before the Parliament today would be subject to variation if we could be persuaded by the procedures committee that it would be in the interests of Parliament to change them as the committee brings its reports progressively before the Parliament. It is not an attempt to restrict, avoid or play down the role of any person in this Parliament; rather, it is an attempt to see that the time set aside for the sitting of Parliament is set aside for the conduct of business. Of course, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who has been attempting to interject, and other honourable members occasionally see an opportunity in the Standing Orders to take up a lot of the time of Parliament, not to conduct business but, they may argue, to exploit the opportunity given to back bench members under the Standing Orders to use that time in that way. Of course, if one makes too much of a good thing, one loses it. That is what has happened in the case of the objection which I suspect the honourable member for Moreton will make later about giving notice of motions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proper process.

—It may have been a proper process but the process was abused. Twenty-seven Ministers were called in at Question Time and understood that questions would start at 2 o'clock and that their programs in the office for seeing people or meeting delegations could be started from 2.45 or 3 o'clock. Instead of that, during the last Parliament we had the spectacle of up to 27 minutes being taken up with notice being given of motions. On two occasions 27 minutes were taken up with notice being given of motions. There were hundreds of them; in the last Parliament, from 1982 to 1984, they trebled. It may seem to the honourable member for Moreton that that was a good use of Parliament, but it fails to attract my sympathy in the proper conduct of this chamber. Consequently, with my powers of debate, I have been able to persuade the Government that we ought to alter the procedure, and the Government has agreed.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that, in the circulation of his amendment, the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Sinclair) has suggested that we could overcome that problem by bringing on notices later in the day so that they do not interfere with Question Time. That is something that a procedures committee can look at. But, in recognition of the fact that we have done away with that time and in recognition also of honourable members' rights, we have extended the adjournment debate from 30 to 45 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal! You have been talking to Valeriy Ivanov again. This sounds more like Moscow to me.

—I think the honourable member for Denison enjoys adjournment debate speeches. His intellect would not take him beyond a five-minute speech. Five-minute speeches are ideal for the Opposition. That is what I think and I suggest that going from 30 to 45 minutes--
—Why didn't you come up with it in the last session?

—Why did the honourable member for Mitchell not get on the front bench? Why did all the New South Welshmen miss out on the front bench? No honourable member made more speeches or gave more notices in the last Parliament than did the honourable member for Mitchell, who sits at the back of the chamber. They did not impress his own Party or the Government and I am really persuaded by his performance that the alteration should be made.

SPEECH.PARA: A few years ago, when the system operated in what we may call a normal way, there was an average of about three notices a day throughout a year. Last year the average was about 12 or 13 notices a day. It was a useless use of the time of this Parliament and was obviously something which should not be allowed to continue. A procedures committee can look at that as well as other measures. The Opposition knows what happens, from when it was in government, when Parliament is used for the useless calling of quorums. When the Fraser Government was in power, if our side of the House called quorums repeatedly, the right honourable member for New England, the then Leader of the House, using all the facilities available under the Standing Orders, would come in and say: 'There you are, fellas. You have 15 Bills and you have an hour to get rid of them. If you want to use up your time calling quorums, that is one thing'.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to put a hammer and sickle on the Speaker's chair?

—The honourable member for Denison should put a hammer and sickle in his mouth. He is talking himself into lasting opposition. I think the fascist Right has got hold of him. I would hate to live under his Standing Orders. Notices of motion can still be given and they will be handed in to the Clerk. In the meantime, we have extended the adjournment debate. It is obvious that the increase in the number of members from 125 to 148 will make--
—Who did that?
—The National Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party did that. It was initiated by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). He put the idea forward.
—That's not right.

—He did. If the honourable member reads Hansard he will find that the honourable member for Boothby was the first person to mention that we should increase the number of members in this Parliament. If the honourable member reads Hansard he will see that I said it was not a very good idea. But then the National Party went out and hired our friend from Duntroon, Malcolm Mackerras. He went before the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and said that it would be a splendid idea. Doug Anthony said: 'If ever you are going to increase the size of the Parliament, now is the time to do it'. But Doug picked up his half a million dollars and whizzed off. It was not going to affect him, but we were left with it. We now have gone from 125 to 148 members and, obviously, those additional members will have some impact in the Parliament. Now is the proper time to have a total review of the procedures which affect our working lives here. We must be able to utilise as best as possible the time available for the sittings of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members opposite know, the other thing about notices of motion is that, unless both parties agree that a motion should be debated, it is not debated. Therefore, notices were simply an attempt at 30, 50 or 100 seconds of propaganda before Question Time. We looked at but finally decided against-I notice that the right honourable member for New England puts forward the idea again-adopting the Canadian system whereby a certain short period of a day is put aside for back bench members to have their say. I am not altogether opposed to that system, but I would prefer--

TALK.START.PARA: —Accept it.
—It may work; it depends on the quality of those sitting opposite and at the moment I am not very impressed.
—Your own side uses these procedures.

—Of course it does, but now that it is in government it is far more responsible. Rather than just grab ideas out of the air and say 'This is what we will do and we hope it works', we have decided to refer the matter to a committee. We have all had experience of working on joint committees. Committees work successfully because when members of parliament are not before the public, they quite sensibly reach valid conclusions about matters referred to them. We will refer to a committee the way the Parliament operates. I do not think any person in this House believes that we have inherited a totally adequate system for the conduct of business in the House of Representatives. It seems to me that the proper way for the system to be totally reviewed is by a procedures committee. If that committee thinks there is some abuse-
—You set up a committee on a tax summit; everything.
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton is continually interjecting. I suggest that if he cannot keep quiet he would do better to get out of the House.

—The honourable member for Moreton has a great love for this institution. He does not want to see anything happen to it. One of these days I will tell honourable members why he loves it. He has a very special reason for loving this place and it has nothing to do with the Standing Orders. He does not care about the Standing Orders.
—Tell us. My wife would like to know too.

—His wife is probably sharing in it. We will not curtail business that goes before a procedures committee. I hope that the Opposition will put its best talent on that committee. We want people with ideas that will make this chamber work better than it has over the last 20, 30 or 40 years. Quite honestly, in the last few years, whenever an idea came up for making the business of this chamber more efficient and to better use the time, the government of the day, whether it was the Fraser Government or the governments before 1972, were always terrified about making any change. They always thought there might be a trick attached, or some advantage to the Opposition, in changing the procedures to which they had become accustomed. In spite of the fact that the right honourable member for New England was a very good Leader of the House, he was not a good leader in terms of the reform of procedures. He too believed that the devil you know is better than the devil you do not know. I believe that we should let a procedures committee look at the procedures of this chamber. We are not making massive radical changes to the Sessional Orders. If that committee has strong views and can reach conclusions about changes it wishes to innovate within this chamber, it can put them to the Parliament and they will receive a very sympathetic hearing from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibility ought to have been given to a committee a long time ago. I am sure that after we have heard from the committee this Parliament will be far more efficient than it is now or has been over the years, merely because of the change of procedures. Those new members who come here and experience the system under which we work in this Parliament, who become accustomed to the fact that they have to run backwards and forwards from their rooms every time the green lights go on-the rooms are getting further and further away in this old Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because you are getting older.

—I am getting older, and wiser. I wish I could say the same for the honourable member; he is just older and wealthier. Ultimately, honourable members, irrespective of the criticisms they may have today, will applaud me in a few weeks time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that last Friday every member of this place realised that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had blown his marbles. He has blown his marbles both in the electorate at large and in this place. The result is that he is no longer prepared to rise here and be subject to the proper criticism and scrutiny that all of us believe he should be subject to. The result of that is that we are now engaged in an absolute farce. The Government is seeking to restrict the rights of every member of this place by making fundamental changes to the Standing Orders. These changes are designed not to protect the rights of the Parliament, but to restrict them. They are designed not to enhance the rights of individual members, but to restrict them. They are designed not to try to favour the general freedom of speech in society, not to enhance our electoral ability, but to ensure that members have less and less time in which to express the points of view for which they were elected to his place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all happening at a time when, as the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has just told us, the membership of the House has been increased by 23, from 125 to 148. Instead of there being more time for members of the House to talk about matters of importance to their electorates and constituents, there is less. Instead of there being a proportional increase in every facet of the proceedings of the Parliament, instead of the Leader of the House saying that, as we have more members we will increase the time given for questions without notice to an hour a day--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Not on your sweet life. Listen to him; he is roaring with laughter over there. He recognises what a fool the Government makes of itself at Question Time. I can well understand his not being prepared to extend Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of giving us a guarantee that there will be an adjournment debate every night, the Leader of the House comes up with the farcical idea that the time for adjournment debates will be extended by 15 minutes. We just happened to look at the number of adjournment debates there have been since we have had a Labor Government. Of 49 sitting days in 1983, on 12 days there was no adjournment debate. Thirteen of those debates were shorter than the 30 minutes now allocated. On 25 of the 49 sitting days we did not even have half an hour for the adjournment debate. On 12 of the days we did not get an adjournment debate at all. Yet the Leader of the House comes in here with his crocodile tears and says: 'We are giving you 15 minutes more for the adjournment'. As if that was not bad enough, in 1984 we had 52 sitting days. On 25 of those 52 sitting days there was no adjournment debate. Yet the Leader of the House says 15 minutes extra will be allocated to the time for such debate according to the Standing Orders. On another eleven of those 52 sitting days, the 30 minutes was restricted. Thus, on 36 of 52 sitting days in 1984 there was some restriction in the amount of time we had to speak on the adjournment debate. The Leader of the House says: 'Oh, gee, I am protecting your interests, boys and girls. Don't worry about it. You will have 15 more minutes'.

I ask honourable members to consider that we have 23 more members and a record whereby in the last two years on more than half the number of sitting days there has been some curtailment of the 30 minutes allocated for the adjournment debate, yet the Leader of the House says he is protecting the rights of private members. What are members on the Government benches doing? I know that the Australian Labor Party has so little interest in the proceedings of the House that most of its members are not here at the moment; but put that aside. Most Labor Party members have no interest in trying to speak on behalf of their constituents or in raising matters on their behalf. Their succumbing to the wiles of the Leader of the House shows their total inability to understand that, unless there is a protection for the private member in this place, there is very little chance of individuals being able to say what they wish and when and where. The Leader of the House has said: 'Yes, but we have a new eight day sitting. It is terribly important that we have a look at the Standing Orders so we are going to eliminate the Standing Orders Committee'. That is what he thinks about providing a better form of sitting for the Parliament. He will set up a new procedures committee. What is in a name? Whether it be called a procedures committee or a Standing Orders committee makes no difference; there has always been such a committee. The Leader of the House thinks that because he changes the name there will be some inherent magic about it. It will change the Standing Orders in exactly the same way or introduce sessional orders as they have always been introduced. That will depend entirely on his preparedness as Leader of the House for the time being-we do not know how long he will be there-to accept that there is a need to try to protect the rights of individual members. But that is really only at the surface of it all.

In 1983 we had a National Economic Summit Conference. We have just been through the trauma of a Federal election. The Labor Party, although it scraped home, did not really do all that well. The election was really about getting members into this Parliament. The Labor Party is not really adept at getting members into this Parliament. It reckons it cannot control Parliament the way it wants to. Where did it hold the National Economic Summit Conference? It held it in this chamber. Where will it hold the national tax summit, or whatever it is to be called? It will also be held here. What is happening in this place? Never mind being elected to Parliament. Never mind worrying about those of us who have our constituencies going back to our constituents promising to raise matters in the Parliament. Oh, no! Henceforth it will not be a matter of being elected to this Parliament; it will be a matter of getting an invitation from the Prime Minister to attend one of these summit nonsenses where everybody gets together in great fun and fellowship and the trade unions go out and write the communique in conjunction with the Hawke-Keating duo. We are now in a position in which the rights of the individual in this place will be enhanced if a summiteer but not if an elected member of Parliament. Frankly, that is not good enough.

We have to understand that the reason that there were so many notices of motion in this Parliament is twofold. I think it was the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) who said that we were a pretty assiduous Opposition; and so we were. We are worried about the sorts of actions that this Government is pursuing that will affect our constituents and the principles in which we believe. It was for that reason we raised notices. Secondly, it is of interest that the number of notices from Government members and Opposition members has been about even. Not only members of the Opposition, but also members of the Government raised them. It is not a matter of it being a one-handed deal. Members on the Government back bench and all members of the Opposition felt frustration at the rare opportunities they had to speak on matters that were of importance to them. We are talking about the rights of individuals on both sides of the House to make contributions on matters that are important to them.

The opportunities for individuals to canvass matters by way of a traditional procedure in this Parliament have existed since Parliament was first created in 1901. The procedure has not been introduced merely over the last few years; it is not something new. It has existed since the beginning of the Parliament. The procedure has been recognised from early times. When the monarch ruled supreme, for example, petitions were a way whereby individuals could get through to those who had authority. In this Parliament, what does the private member do? He used to have an opportunity to stand on his feet and give notice about matters that affected his principles, his electorate, his constituents, or about any other matter that he believed was within the Standing Orders and worthy of being canvassed. Under this new procedure, notices of motion will be hidden away in the Notice Paper. The Notice Paper will become compulsory reading for us all. We will have to read it assiduously to see who has been saying what about whom. The only person to know about the notices will be Mr Speaker himself. He will receive the notices and be able to say yea or nay. Not a soul in the electorate or in the Parliament will know the content of those notices unless he assiduously reads the Notice Paper. That is not always easy to do.

So, looking at the expanded Parliament and recognising that there is a real need in this place to do as the Leader of the House has suggested and not to stick with the practices that have always been followed, we decided that it was essential to see whether we could improve them, and make a couple of significant modifications. I have suggested two such modifications. We all understand that the giving of notices of motion can be disruptive to the timetables and schedules of busy Ministers and members. It is sometimes difficult, when one has people waiting outside, to have to be in the Parliament for an indeterminate period while waiting to see whether one's particular item of business can be concluded. So I have suggested that first, we place a time limit-I have suggested 10 minutes-on the time allocated for the giving of oral notices. Perhaps a longer period might be satisfactory, but I think 10 minutes is a bare minimum.

Secondly, I have suggested that we change the order of considering notices. Notices do not have to be given at the beginning of proceedings. They could be given, perhaps, after petitions on a sitting Tuesday or, when the House begins in the morning, immediately after petitions, which, honourable members will recall, under our present Sessional Orders, are read at the beginning of our proceedings. After prayers and petitions we could have notices for 10 minutes. I believe that would be an equitable way of meeting the valid concern that the Minister has put forward which is that too much time can be taken out of proceedings for notices. I believe that to have a 10-minute time limit for the giving of oral notices would be a very worthwhile and efficient way of protecting the rights of honourable members, recognising that there are 23 more of us in this place, and ensuring that there is a reasonable opportunity of canvassing matters of great significance. That is really the only way the matter can be handled. Of course, the elaborate procedures which enables an honourable member to move a motion of censure or to raise a very real problem by suspending Standing Orders can still continue. However, frankly I am apprehensive that the way this Government is going it may even want to cut out our voices in that respect, too. I believe that it is essential that there be at least a 10-minute oral notice period.

I believe that my amendment would accommodate another procedure. It concerns 90-second statements being allowed to be made by members. I am told that in the United States House of Representatives a period has been allocated for the giving of 60-second statements by members for as long as their officers can remember. In other words, the practice goes back a long way. The United States House of Representatives is a democratic institution, unlike this place under this Government. There is no restriction on either the content of the 60-second statements or the total period allocated for them. Any decision is left entirely to the discretion of the Speaker. If there is pressing government business the Speaker will, of his own volition, defer the statements, or some of them, to later in the day when the business has been completed. Honourable members should notice that there is no restriction on either the content of the statements or the total period allocated for them.

Honourable members should contrast that procedure with the procedures we have here. We do not even have a 90-second or a 60-second statement period. It must be recognised, however, that in the United States, as there are no Ministers in the House, there is no Question Time. To a degree, the 60-second statement period is a substitute. However, of course, the United States House of Representatives has a different sort of procedure. We all know that congressional hearings in the United States give individual members of Congress an opportunity to question the members of the United States Cabinet.

In the Canadian House of Commons, which is similarly under the Westminster system, a 90-second statement system was introduced for private members in 1983. It is regarded as being one of the most successful innovations in the House for years. The House meets at 11 a.m. on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays and at 2 p.m. on Wednesdays. At 2 p.m. on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, immediately after the suspension of the sitting for lunch on Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays and after prayers on Wednesdays, and at 11 a.m. after prayers on Fridays, the Speaker calls on statements by members. The Standing Orders do not provide for the length of the period but instead provide that at 2.15 p.m. on all days except Fridays and at 11.15 a.m. on Fridays oral questions be called on. There are certain restraints on what they may contain. Members can be instructed to resume their seats if there are personal attacks, if there is any attempt to move a motion or if the statement contains a congratulatory message or what are clearly frivolous issues.

I believe that congratulatory messages are desirable. We all remember the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) last year congratulating the victors in the Sydney Rugby League competition. What is wrong with his doing that? Why does not the Minister who is at the table want his own colleagues to be able to congratulate the down town football team? I believe that a procedure of that ilk would be an advantage in this place. Therefore, I propose in the motion before the House that there be a 12-minute statement period in addition to a 10-minute oral notice period. There would be a 12-minute period within which it would be possible for honourable members on both sides of the House to make statements for a maximum of 90 seconds. I believe that procedure would protect the interests of members of the Parliament and give honourable members on both sides of the House an opportunity to present their views more adequately than they can do now. I therefore move the amendment that has been circulated in my name, that all words after 'that' be omitted with a view to substituting the two very commendable practices of ten minutes of oral notices and 12 minutes of oral statements of no more than 90 seconds duration, which would genuinely enhance democracy in this place instead of inhibiting it which the motion moved by the Leader of the House, I am afraid, will do. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. We often hear statements by the Leader of the House (Mr Young), who is sitting at the table, that he belongs to a democratic government and a democratic Australian Labor Party. However, when one looks at the figures that characterise the performance of this Government one finds that it is the least democratic government since Federation. In fact, even in the statement of the Minister today he complained vigorously about members of parliament having to come to the Parliament. He said that they would rather be back in their electorates. I remind the Labor Party that people are elected to the Parliament. This is where their jobs reside. This is where they do their jobs. This is where they represent the wishes of their constituents. What the Minister and this Government have done is to prevent members of Parliament from both sides of the House from doing their jobs effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of individual taste, I guess, and I understand the difficulty of members who have come from a long away, but the sittings of the House as they presently are constituted make it very difficult indeed for back bench committees to operate effectively in this House. Of course, we all know the importance of committees in informing members of legislation, in allowing points of view to be put forward which may characteristically be against the Government's point of view. The Minister at the table also complained that Ministers have to come in here and occasionally wait. I remind him that Ministers are members of Parliament. They are not exalted beings. They would not be Ministers unless they were members of Parliament. Their first duty is to this Parliament. I wonder whether this Government really is supportive of the concepts of a Westminster style of government at all. We all know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) considers himself to be the potential first President of this nation. However, when we see the concentration on summits on every conceivable aspect of public life, we wonder whether the Government in power at present really supports the concept of parliamentary democracy.

Let me look at some of the performances of the Government since it has come to power. In relation to the rights of ordinary members of parliament-not the Ministers not the Government, but members of parliament-my colleague, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), has already raised the question of adjournment debates. He mentioned the number of adjournment debates that have been held. Adjournment debates are very important for back bench members of the Parliament. They give back bench members of the Parliament the opportunity to raise issues of interest to them and their constituents in an unhindered sense. What has been the performance of this Government since it has come to power? The number of adjournment debates has been the lowest of any parliament since 1963. For the first time since 1963 this Government has brought about the lowest number of adjournment debates, in two successive years. What a performance for a Government which claims to represent the people, to preside over a democratic society, to be a democratic party. Every aspect of democracy which allows members of parliament to put forward their points of view is stifled by the actions of this Minister and this Government.

In the first year of the Fraser Government, 1976, there were 10 grievance debates. In 1977 there were nine grievance debates. The number of grievance debates averaged about nine throughout the time of the Fraser Government. As soon as the Hawke Government came to power, down the figures went to an average of seven grievance debates.

I turn to questions without notice. Here we have a situation in which back bench-and front bench-members of parliament can ask Ministers questions of which, at least from our side, they have not been given prior knowledge. Let us have a look at the Government's performance in this area-the effective scrutiny of a government. In 1976, the first full year of a Fraser Government, there were 1,447 questions without notice. In the second year there were 1,021. But what of this Government, which again purports to be the best government-certainly since the war years. The Prime Minister proudly boasts that his Ministers are the best since the war years. If they are the best since the war years, why are they so scared to answer questions without notice? Why do they run away from answering questions without notice? Why do we have the record in 1983 of only 597 questions without notice? The Government did even better in 1984; it reduced that number to 591. The Ministers of the best government since the Second World War do not have the courage to come here and face questions without notice. Not only do they not have the courage, they do not have the information.

Let us look at the average number of questions without notice answered by members of this Government. It has averaged around 12 to 12.7 per day. Not only do we have the numbers of days of sitting reduced, we also have the numbers of questions without notice reduced, the number of adjournment debates reduced, the number of grievance debates reduced and now we have the number of notices of motion being reduced. How can any Labor member of parliament honestly report back to his or her constituency and say that he or she represents a democratic form of government? In every way this Minister and this Government are curtailing Labor members' rights as back benchers. Government members should be very conscious of their extreme responsibility and extreme privilege of being members of this Parliament. They should be defending the rights of members of parliament as assiduously as this Minister is trying to detract from them. There have been a great number of members of parliament since Federation and all of them have sought to protect the sanctity of this institution and to enhance its importance. But in the two years that the Hawke Government has been in power, it has sought at every turn and at every opportunity to reduce the importance of parliament and the opportunities of members of parliament to put forward their points of view in relation to their constituents in what should be the greatest forum in this land-the Parliament of Australia. It is absolutely appalling that the Minister can come here and, in his usual cheerful fashion, put forward, quite straightfaced, the proposition that he is after all protecting the rights of backbench members of parliament. Nothing could be further from the truth and the proof of that is in the statistics which are available and which cannot be refuted. I challenge the Minister to get up and say: 'Yes, we are in favour of more questions without notice'.

TALK.START.PARA: —All my back benchers are happy.

—Well, let us hear a ringing endorsement from the back bench members. I wonder whether they are all happy about not having the opportunity to answer questions without notice. If they are, that is the most damning indictment of any political party that I have ever heard. It is a damning indictment when a Minister can get up and say that the Government has reduced the number of opportunities for back bench members to ask questions without notice and they say they are happy about it. They have been cowed into submission; the factions have got to them. It is more important to be able to ask a question without notice in one's individual faction than it is to be able to ask a question within the national Parliament. That is what the Government has reduced this Parliament to, and I think it is an absolutely shocking statement. Not only is the Minister capable of making such a statement, but his back benchers are prepared to sit there quietly without any objections while he makes it. I am certain that members on this side of the House will take back to their constituents the fact that Labor Party members of parliament are quite happy to be muzzled and gagged. They are quite happy to sit there mute in the face of the performance such as that given today by the Special Minister of State.

SPEECH.PARA: There are quite legitimate suggestions being put forward as to how the procedures of the House should operate. I really believe that behind any proposition for alteration of the procedures of the House, we should keep in mind the importance of this institution. Every change should be designed to enhance the status of this institution in the community. Every proposition should be put forward in the belief that individual members of parliament, whether they be Ministers or back benchers, whether they be in government or in opposition, have the opportunity to take part in debates on the great issues of the day and, at the same time, have the opportunity to bring forward matters of concern to them and their constituents. That is what we are here for; that is what we are elected for; that is what we are paid for. We are not paid to be back in the electorates; we are paid to be in the Parliament, representing the people who elected us or who are in our constituencies.

I acknowledge that there are proper suggestions for alterations to our procedures but I suggest that the background to those alterations should be designed to enhance the Parliament and the opportunities of individual members to put forward their views. The fact is that every change so far brought in by this Government and this Minister has detracted from the status of the Parliament as an institution and has reduced the opportunities available to individual members to put forward their points of view. The Opposition, rather than being negative, has put forward positive suggestions. I urge the Minister and the Government to take these suggestions in the spirit in which they have been put forward. We believe these suggestions would do much to add something to the opportunities available to individual members of parliament and to make certain that the constant reduction in such opportunities is at least halted for a moment. It would also give an opportunity for a further committee to review all the procedures and come up with further suggestions. We put forward this amendment in a spirit of seeking to improve the workings of the House and we suggest that the Government should accept it. Certainly, we suggest to individual back bench members of the Government that they should look very carefully at propositions which further reduce their opportunities as members of parliament. One's position as a member of parliament should transcend any party political allegiance in the final analysis. I know that that is a terribly difficult concept for a member of the Labor Party to take in but, in fact, that is the way it should be. If a parliamentary democracy is to work and if Parliament is to remain a great institution, individual members of parliament must pay the utmost respect to that institution and to their privileges and opportunities within it.

If any government, of any political persuasion, seeks to reduce the opportunities of individual members of parliament to play their role in that Parliament properly, those individuals should revolt against such a proposition. Our proposals are positive and they enhance the status of the Parliament. They also provide opportunities for back bench members and I urge the Government to accept them. If the Government will not accept them, I urge Government members to show a little bit of courage and support them.

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
May it please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

I am pleased and honoured to move this motion on behalf of the Government and I thank my colleagues for the privilege. Firstly, Mr Speaker, in accordance with convention, may I congratulate you on your re-election to your high and important office. I understand and have observed during my short time here that you discharge your duties fairly and in a good natured manner. From all accounts, the respect which members of this House have for you personally equals the respect they have for the position which you hold. I assure you of my co-operation during my term in this House. I congratulate also the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees on her re-election and on the high esteem in which she is held in this House.

I enter this Parliament as a member of the Australian Labor Party and as the elected representative of the people of Cowan in Western Australia. By electing me, the residents of Cowan have indicated their approval of and support for the Hawke Government's achievements during its first term in office and for the continuance of its policies of economic reconstruction and national reconciliation. In accepting the privilege the electors have conferred upon me, I undertake to represent them to the very best of my ability.

The seat of Cowan was formed as a result of the redistribution last year and comprises the northern segment of the old Stirling electorate and the southern section of the old Moore electorate. I am indebted to my colleagues the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) for their ministrations, in days gone by, to the residents of what is now my electorate. As the beneficiary of their, and the Labor Party's, electoral goodwill, I thank them. The electorate is named after Edith Cowan, the first woman to enter Parliament in Australia and only the second woman to achieve that distinction in the British Empire-the first being Lady Astor. It is claimed that when Edith Cowan was first elected the Age warned that if her example were to inspire other women there would be 'many dreary and neglected homes throughout the country sacrificed on the altar of political ambition'. I hasten to assure the House, and the Age, that my home is no more dreary or neglected now that I am a member of parliament than it was before I became one. Indeed, I gladly and gratefully acknowledge the support and assistance I have received from my husband and my children in reaching this place.

The welfare of women and children was always of great concern to Edith Cowan, and her work in founding the King Edward Memorial Hospital for Women in Western Australia is well known. Mrs Cowan was also associated with the Children's Protection Society and she founded the Women's Service Guild. She was an outstanding personality in the women's movement both in Western Australia and Australia, and was an active and courageous social reformer. Edith Cowan always hoped that the way she had paved for women's representation in the Parliament would be followed by more members of her sex. As a woman I am proud to have followed her example. I applaud her achievements and her memory and am privileged to represent the electorate which honours her name.

Those honourable members who are familiar with Western Australia's geography and demography will appreciate that the electorate of Cowan is situated in the northern growth corridor of Perth's metropolitan area. It is primarily a residential seat with large numbers of homes under purchase and/or construction. Many of the newer residents have benefited from the Government's first home owners scheme and many more have been assisted by its achievements in lowering interest rates and inflation. Because families in my electorate, by and large, face substantial mortgage repayments, they are particularly sensitive to movements in interest rates and associated economic policy. Others, who are not in a position to build or buy their own homes, are concerned about the allocation of Federal money to public housing through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

The majority of residents in Cowan have relatively young families and are extremely concerned about taxation policy. The Institute of Family Studies has found that between 1975-76 and 1984-85 families with children had the highest tax increases, with large families encountering the greatest average tax rate increases. Accordingly, I welcome the taxation review which is to take place later this year and the Government's undertaking to make the tax system fairer, simpler and more efficient. It is imperative that income be redistributed more equitably and more progressively. Together with the taxation review, the Government has signalled its intention to reintroduce the bottom of the harbour Bills which were rejected during the last Parliament. In doing so it has clearly renewed its commitment to give the highest priority to measures against tax avoidance and evasion, which constantly undermine the equity of our taxation system.

As a person interested in and concerned about issues affecting women in our community, I count myself fortunate to be a member of a government which possesses such a formidable record of action in this area. In particular, the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women was a milestone in Australia's political history. It is pleasing to note that the Government's affirmative action pilot program is receiving excellent co-operation from the companies and departments involved. One of its major achievements to date has been the improvement in community attitudes towards women, especially in terms of employment. In my electorate women with children have a desperate need for more child care and family day care services. The Government's commitment to create an additional 20,000 child care places will hopefully mean that they can look forward to an improvement in their position in the near future. Discussions are currently taking place between Federal, State and local government representatives in the Wanneroo area with a view to ensuring maximum community involvement in the provision of children's services and a substantial increase in the care available.

The Governor-General's address also refers to Australia's participation in International Youth Year activities. Young people are the foundation of our future as a nation and I am confident that the foreshadowed examination of issues affecting young Australians will realistically address the problems of youth unemployment and homelessness, among other things. Too many young people in my electorate are affected by the tragedy of unemployment and suffer the problems of despondency and low self-esteem which long periods out of work inevitably induce. Some of these young people have become involved with community youth support scheme groups in the area and others have taken up activities organised by education program for unemployed youth, or EPUY, groups. Many have been assisted by the Government's employment creation initiatives through the community employment program, which is designed to assist disadvantaged groups and individuals.

Prospects for teenage job seekers remain optimistic as a result of the Government's in principle acceptance of the Kirby recommendations on youth traineeships and its intention to move urgently in the youth policy area. Where youth employment is concerned it is also necessary to encourage actively private enterprise to adopt a more responsible and sympathetic attitude to employment generation and training for young people. Furthermore, employer groups need to shelve their constantly reiterated calls for a reduction of youth wage rates as a solution to youth unemployment. It is nothing more than a recipe for the exploitation of young people already in the work force. To the extent that more jobs may be provided for young people, these would necessarily be at the expense of adults-possibly those with families to support-who are presently employed in relatively unskilled occupations. The net contribution of such a scheme to the overall problem of unemployment would be nil and young people in the work force would find themselves substantially worse off in wage terms.

At this stage I pay tribute to two groups in my electorate which have been working to assist unemployed young people for some considerable time. Both groups have shown initiative and determination in the way they have responded to particular obstacles and challenges confronting them. The Whitfords community youth support scheme has acquired its own building and has now embarked on a project to extend a helping hand to another needy and worthwhile organisation which arranges therapeutic activities for the disabled. This group-CATA as it is known-is seeking government financial assistance but has the misfortune of failing to fit into any of the funding avenues available to groups providing valuable community services. The Balga community youth support scheme has been operating in extremely cramped premises for some time and has now taken the matter into its own hands by launching an appeal for funds from the public for the specific purpose of overcoming its accommodation difficulties. I wish both organisations well in their respective endeavours now and in the future. The work that they do is greatly appreciated by the community at large as well as by the young unemployed people they so ably assist.

There is also a need within my electorate for another community youth support scheme in the Girrawheen area where unemployment levels are disproportionately high. I shall continue to pursue this matter through the appropriate channels. I also gratefully acknowledge the efforts of the Anglican health and welfare services in pursuit of Skills West funding for a program to improve the employment skills of women in the Girrawheen area and their endeavours to gain the support of local employers for an employer attachment scheme involving work experience and training.

The Governor-General, in his Speech, also referred to the Government's intention to establish principles for national land rights legislation in recognition of the fundamental importance of the land to Aborigines. As Australians we must all acknowledge, accept and honour the historical debt we owe to the Aboriginal people, whose traditional lands were acquired by early white settlers without the benefit of a treaty. Racism and paternalism can no longer be tolerated in this country. Aboriginal people must be permitted to reclaim as much of their heritage as possible. Their dignity as a people and their future participation as citizens of this country depend upon this being achieved. The eyes of the world are on Australia over this question. No amount of political posturing will disguise attempts to shy away from our national obligation in this significant and long overdue area of basic human rights. I am pleased to acknowledge the support and encouragement of many church and community groups in my electorate and elsewhere in Australia on this aspect of Federal Government endeavour.

Another area of national and international importance, which this Government is squarely facing up to, is the issue of peace and disarmament. As a member of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom I urge the government to continue its efforts to promote the proposals for a South Pacific nuclear-free zone and an Indian Ocean zone of peace. In the same vein, I extend my sincere congratulations to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Federal Labor Caucus on the courage of their decision to review the commitment relating to MX missile tests. As the Prime Minister has pointed out, this issue is of great concern to a broad section of the Australian community. There is a groundswell of public opinion and the Government would have been insensitive and irresponsible to have ignored that opinion.

As stated in the Governor-General's Speech, this Government remains deeply and firmly committed to advancing the cause of peace, arms control and disarmament. I am confident that it will continue to have the fortitude and determination necessary to respond to the wishes of the people on issues of national importance such as these. After all, as Edith Cowan is reported to have said, the aim of all parliaments should be the peace and happiness of those for whom they legislate. I thank honourable members for their attention.
