The Governor-General's Speech to members of the Parliament of Australia is a blueprint for continuing growth. If we put the nation's interests before selfish indulgence surely we must accept that the Government's program, embracing a reconciliation between separated elements of our society, coupled with a co-operative effort for the common good, is the only path to follow. Gone are the past animosities pitting Australians against Australians to achieve cheap and temporary gains for some. Gone are the mutual suspicions fostered for so long that restricted our development. In their place we have a new relationship of co-operation and it has produced results. We will build on these successes as this Government takes us into our bicentenary and beyond. It is an appropriate tribute to this Government that it has been entrusted by the Australian people to take us through this very important time in our history.

The economy is making great strides towards full recovery. The prices and incomes accord has led to real and lasting gains for all Australians. The Government's economic programs are successful. His Excellency made it clear in his speech that they will continue. At the coming tax summit all will be invited to contribute their ideas to decide what changes might take place. The Government will extend its employment and community welfare programs. Greater resources will be directed towards further improvements in education and other initiatives to achieve a stronger, fairer and more equitable society.

I take this opportunity to thank my campaign workers in St George for, without their tireless efforts, I might not be here today. I particularly thank my wife, Annette, for her endurance, advice and understanding. Never once during those long days and what seemed even longer nights did she fail to be anything but my most energetic worker. I thank Mrs Val Backvall for her generous support through the election campaign and I thank the many other workers too numerous to name individually. I am also indebted to my predecessor, Bill Morrison, a neighbour, a good family friend and a political colleague for many years. I have always respected his advice and valued the close rapport we have enjoyed for many years. I wish the Morrison family well as they continue to serve Australia's interests in another role.

The division of St George was created in 1948 and I am honoured to be the seventh member to represent the interests of all the people of St George in this Parliament. The electorate of St George has been represented by the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia four times each prior to my election. Two members have represented the seat twice, the first was Bruce Graham and the other was Bill Morrison. I am the first member for St George to follow a predecessor from the same political party. A great Labor tradition has commenced. I am aware of the impressive record that Bill Morrison made here as a parliamentarian and a Minister, and I am honoured to take the baton from him. St George was once regarded as a most marginal electorate. I am grateful that Bill left it in such good shape. I will ensure that St George will always remain a safe Labor seat.

I first came to Australia in 1951, as a child, from a place now known as Vanuatu. It was there, as a child, even though I was a member of a privileged class, that I found I could not accept the glaring differences between the standard of living enjoyed by the European colonists and that of the Melanesian people. It was there that my deep compassion for the underprivileged was formed and the seeds of my later political commitment were sown. I still retain my compassion and deep commitment to assist the less fortunate.

It was not until late 1972 that being an Australian took on a new dimension for me and for millions of my fellow citizens. We had gone through a period when privilege had become entrenched, Australia was regarded as a European appendage in Asia and we suffered from the disastrous involvement in Vietnam. But all this came to an end with the election of a Labor Government. For me this was the time when Australia came of age and my commitment to the great principles of the Australian Labor Party have not diminished since that time.

Late in 1984 I was called by my Party to contest the seat of St George. Once again the electors of St George declared their support for the Labor Party and I was sent here to join my colleagues to form the second Hawke Labor Government. The people of St George joined other Australians in reaffirming their faith in the Government and gave it a clear mandate to continue the work it had started-to build a better, fairer and more prosperous society. They had good reason to place their trust once more in a government dedicated to improving the lot of so many who had been neglected in the past.

St George is a compact suburban electorate of some 31 square kilometres. Those honourable members who have flown to Sydney would most likely have flown over it. While they would be most warmly welcomed, the aircraft noise many of our residents have had to suffer over the years is not so welcome. The residents of St George were at last offered some hope of relief from this noise pollution when the Labor Government took some positive steps in looking for a site for Sydney's second major airport.

The people of St George have made welcome a significant number of migrants from Greece, Italy, Yugoslavia, Lebanon and many other parts of the world. The problems of resettlement are many and varied and I am committed to helping these people find their place in this great country of ours. They know the solid achievements of the Labor Government and the continuation of those policies will create more jobs to alleviate the higher than average unemployment level among the migrant communities. They know that the value of their savings has been protected from the ravages of high inflation. They know that we can achieve our goals by working together. They know this Government is committed to ensuring that there will be no second class citizens in Australia. St George has all the richness of a mixed community working together in harmony with understanding and tolerance.

The young people of St George, who will become the men and women of tomorrow, can look forward to their future with confidence. They will continue to benefit from the programs that will provide jobs and expand the opportunities for those who wish to continue their education. The foundation stones have been laid for a better tomorrow. With a young family myself, I understand their aspirations and I will be aiming to assist my young constituents to extend their education and in getting jobs.

The senior citizens of St George, whose past labours have given us what we have today, know that they can enjoy their well earned retirement in dignity. They were recently subjected to disgraceful scare tactics designed to frighten them into voting against a Labor government that has always in the past, and indeed will in the future, look after their interests. They contributed to that vote of confidence in this Government and their trust is well placed. To all the citizens of St George I repeat the pledge I gave to the electors: I will strive diligently and energetically to serve their interests and to make St George an even better place to live. The electors gave me a clear signal, with such a comfortable majority at the 1 December election, that they want me to contribute as a member of this Government to building a better future for Australia. I look forward to the task ahead of us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to remember that the Speech delivered by His Excellency, the Governor-General, was written by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), or more likely by his speech writers. The in words under this second Hawke Government promise to be 'inadequate, inconsistent, incompetent and insincere'. Definitely out is the word 'integrity'. TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish.

If anything this Government has claimed for and of itself, that is the most damning. After a mere two years we are urged to believe that Australia has witnessed the strongest and most sustained economic performance for decades. Never mind that the Australian currency has depreciated to its lowest level since Federation. Never mind that the deficit on the current accounts of the balance of payments is going through the roof. Never mind the highest Budget, accumulated deficits and attendant interest on borrowings in living memory. Never mind all that and more; we are being asked to believe Australia has experienced the strongest and most sustained economic performance for decades. Heaven help us. It is absolute rubbish of the sort that brings politicians into disrepute. So too is the entreaty to this Parliament to provide the legislative basis on which the Prime Minister claimed commitments to the electorate are to be carried out. When has this Prime Minister earned accolades for keeping his election promises? In less than two years in office he has broken and failed to keep more election pledges than any Prime Minister this century.
—Ask my grape growers.
—Ask the grape growers. Ask a lot of people. Ask the elderly, ask the kids trying to get into colleges or universities, ask a whole bunch of people around the country.
—Ask the unemployed.

—Ask the unemployed. Undoubtedly the Prime Minister is the world record holder for broken election promises. If, as stated, it is the Government's intention to maintain its approach to economic policy, we should pray that that will be another broken promise. If that one is not broken there will be more pressure on the Australian dollar, there will be more pressure on the balance of payments and the levels of our reserves, and there will be more pressure for big deficits for future generations of taxpayers to service and repay.

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been difficult for rational people to accept the so-called prices and incomes accord as anything like a sustainable panacea for our economic well-being and progress. The ink was hardly dry on that apology for a binding agreement before the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) was scouting for a way in which the building industry unions could subvert its provisions. That little episode has not yet reached its conclusion but it will after the next national wage case is decided. Then, with the Minister's support, we will see a campaign for a non-contributory, industry funded superannuation impost at an amount struck by or with the connivance of the Minister. Accord or no accord, the cost of employment will continue to escalate at a rate far greater than inflation as measured by the consumer price index.

The big government backed assaults on the costs of employment during the coming year will include two national wage case increases. These will go hand in hand with the widespread imposition of compulsory superannuation in industries in which, until now, it was purely voluntary, and supplemented by implementation of a national occupational health and safety program. On top of that there is likely to be a cost to employers in meeting the, as yet, undefined demands of that other arm of government under an Australian Labor Party administration, more commonly known as the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Altogether the expected blowout in the costs of employment will have dire consequences for our unemployed and our standard of living.

On the one hand it is not much good for the Government to be expressing universal concern for those who have experienced the effects of prolonged unemployment while, on the other hand, it continues to foster and support wage structures which will perpetuate high levels of prolonged unemployment. There is not much to be said for a commitment to centralised wage fixing and an archaic industrial relations system which condemns so many of our breadwinners and our youth to entrenched, irreversible unemployment.

This incompetent Government has thrown up its hands and admitted that hard core and long term unemployment are too hard to handle. It is walking away from the problem. This is evidenced by its propaganda-like mind conditioning rhetoric but only because it is unable to escape the manacles applied by its masters in the unions and the claustrophobic limitations of its accord with the ACTU. The infamous accord, which is the equivalent of Neville Chamberlain's peace in our time deception, is now being seen for what it is not. It is not a formula for industrial peace in our time, as evidenced by the debacle of the recent Public Service strike, which has been euphemistically described as a work bans campaign, or unabated strikes and industrial disruption throughout the building industry.

The strength of the accord in curbing the excesses of unions is a hairless Samson if the industrial sabotage of grain and coal handling facilities is remembered. Countless industrial relations issues have simmered uncertainly and boilovers are now even more in prospect, and this Government will be powerless to act unless it can break the bonds of its accord with the unions and exercise the right and duty of a democratically elected government, which, after all, is elected to govern all Australians. That it has the ability to govern for all is doubtful; that it has the will is improbable; that it and its Prime Minister have the integrity is simply out of the question.

Not only has the Government walked away from difficult industrial relations problems but also it has abandoned economic problems largely of its own making. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has simply thrown up his hands and walked away from the burgeoning growth in the supply of money. Because his target of an 8 to 10 per cent growth in M3 was exceeded in both November and December-it reached 11.8 per cent-it is all too much to be bothered with. The January figure for M3 which is to be announced this week will probably show that it is growing at a rate of around 12.5 per cent or some 25 to 30 per cent above the Treasurer's forecast for this financial year.

Despite the expectations of sane men everywhere, corrective action is not even being contemplated. This blowout is only part of the picture anyway. Probably more important is the growth of broad money supply, and that is also out of control. However, the Treasurer's response is the same. He is doing nothing. He is ignoring his own forecasts and refusing to issue amended predictions now that it is inevitable that his earlier goals cannot be met. That is hardly imaginative or responsible fiscal management. It will be steady as she goes under this Government, even if that means going steadily down the gurgler. There is to be nothing like bringing forward the projected May bond tender and testing the market by seeking around $1,000m to soak up excess liquidity. That theme or a variation of it would go some way towards reassuring domestic and overseas investors and observers. The nomination of new money supply goals, if coupled with a believable undertaking to stick to them, would go some way towards restoring faith and confidence.

If the Treasurer is content to continue to sit on his hands and do nothing to restore confidence by taking positive steps to tell the nation that the growth of money is receiving attention, at least he may be cajoled into making the most of the collapse of the Australian dollar. If we must live with his fiscal ineptitude, we could at least go some way towards taking a golden opportunity to match the rhetoric of successive governments and reduce the levels of tariff and other protection. I say it is a golden opportunity because depreciation of the international value of our dollar by around 15 per cent means that large sections of our protected manufacturing industry are approaching 30 per cent more competitive against imports. That is a direct consequence of the deflation of our dollar and it is a golden opportunity to do those things which successive Prime Ministers have said overseas, repeated time and again in international forums while away from these shores and have come back to this country and ignored.

Apart from being in line with the stated preferences of many in the Government and Opposition parties alike, lowering the tariff would help to ameliorate the inflationary effects of both the cascading dollar and the blowout in the stocks of money. Of course, it would be too much to expect the Treasurer to do the right thing then and amend the Government's submission to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by telling it that the Government's argument in favour of a 2.6 or 2.7 per cent across the board wage increase was predicated on wrong forecasts and wrong information. It would be too much to expect the Government to say: 'Because we did have the wrong information, because the figures we now have tell a completely different story, we have to submit to the Commission that there should be no 2.6 or 2.7 per cent increase across the board. The economy of the country will not now stand it, nor will the employers of Australia cop it and still be able to maintain employment'. That would be too responsible.

While the Prime Minister admits to fallibility, albeit when caught by his left wing with his MX exposed, we have yet to hear the Treasurer confess to his mistakes or miscalculations; nor, it seems, are we likely to hear him. Much is happening under this socialist Government that is worrying for decent Australians, who look to the Commonwealth for strong leadership. We are witnessing the transition from the first Hawke Government to a government of appeasement-from the first Hawke Government of broken and unkept promises to a government of appeasement. Most of all, the transition is apparent within the Australian Labor Party where we see appeasement of its Left faction, its Centre Left faction, its broad Left faction, its Centre faction, its Right faction, its independents and, through them, a plethora of minority interest groups. Leadership is diminishing as we see the dominance of the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the Government and the growing influence of an irrational nuclear disarmament movement, as well as the growing influence of apologists for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics masquerading as unilateral disarmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are taking control.

—They are taking control, indeed. We see other groups getting increasing comfort from this Government as it finds itself locked into the union movement and the minority interest groups of which I have spoken. Amongst those receiving increasing comfort are mediocre educators with mediocre education standards. We are seeing the appeasement of those who would like to see a massive transfer of resources from the wealth-creating achievers by oppressive taxes and government charges. We are seeing comfort being given to those who would diminish our ability to develop a credible defence force. We are seeing comfort being given to those who denigrate and undermine our defence and trade alliances with the free countries of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: On the last occasion on which I spoke in an Address-in-Reply debate, which was early in 1983, I said that there is much for this Government to do. Leadership has to be shown. There is little evidence of it but it is not too late. Despite my desire to see in government my Party, in coalition with the National Party of Australia, the affairs of Australia demand that we have responsible leadership from the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —God save Australia.

—God save Australia, indeed; never mind Sir John Kerr. We have seen an abdication of responsibility by the Prime Minister, ably supported by his Ministry. I said in 1983, and I say again, that the thing confronting Australia, apart from the need for leadership and strong and positive management of this country's affairs, is concentration on our economy. The Government should stop trying to chase every rabbit down every burrow and get on with the job of managing the country and its economy. It should ignore the diversions of those outrageous reformers who seek to influence it. They should await their day and their turn and allow the Government to get on with the business of managing the economy of this country and keeping us out of the unholy mess that we will be in if it does not accept its responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume this Government will go its full term, unlike the previous one. The Prime Minister would be unlikely to pull on an early election, although no one could doubt his wisdom in calling the election held on 1 December. It is now patently clear that, had that election not taken place, the coalition parties would have been returned to government. The Prime Minister's timing was impeccable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see the last Bulletin poll?

—The Bulletin polls indicated that. Unlike the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), those of us parliamentarians who seek to represent our electors rather than serve the government of the day, know from feelings within our electorates that opinions have changed radically and dramatically since 1 December. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, before I commence my speech, I lend my congratulations to those who have gone before in congratulating you on your election to high office and to express my pleasure at seeing you again in the chair. Prior to the last 20 minutes, I had decided that I should resist the temptation to comment on the Opposition's trivialising of issues facing Australia. But, having sat through the speech by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), I find it very hard not to comment on the contradictions and waffle in it. I suggest that anybody who takes the trouble to read the speeches by Opposition members should look very closely at the inherent contradictions and sheer nonsense in them.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Address-in-Reply debate I think it is appropriate to pick up a statement from the Governor-General's Speech. I refer to page 8 of that Speech. The Governor-General said:

The Government will continue to attach the highest importance to its efforts to achieve defence self-reliance. Within the parameters of economic policy, it will increase investment in the capacities of Australian industry to design, manufacture and maintain defence force equipment.
(Quorum formed) I certainly must express my admiration for the great improvement in the skill and cleverness of the Opposition in its tactics in the House; I see it has really learned something!

I return to the Governor-General's Speech. He speaks of the highest importance being attached to achieving self-reliance in defence. Self-reliance is a term that comes to mind easily but it has enormous implications for Australia. In the late 1930s and early 1940s this nation relied on defence pacts to protect the future of the country. We went from being a nation with virtually no defence manufacturing capacity in 1941 to being one of the world's foremost aeronautical manufacturers and munitions manufacturers by the late 1940s. Certainly Australian industry and the Australian people showed their capacity to become self-reliant when the need arose.

In the last 35 years Australia has been taken back by our predecessors to the situation of the early 1940s. For the previous speaker to talk about defence and defence policy for Australia is a sham and a fraud. The former Government perpetrated on Australia perhaps the most cruel hoax and one of the most cruel deceptions the country has ever seen: The illusion of a defence Force that does not exist. The illusion was created by buying fancy pieces of equipment which, on the surface, matched the world's best, but which have a non-existent quality and capacity to fuel. The example that springs most vividly to mind is that of the Leopard tanks which are fine so long as we do not decide to have a war with the people who make the shells, because if we did we would not have any shells for them to fire.

Defence self-reliance could become the most important movement for the defence forces, the people and the government of the country. Self-reliance offers us a chance to re-establish in our defence forces and our community a sense of national pride and national capacity. Let us face it: Who takes particularly seriously a country that has to rely on many other countries to furnish its armaments and its weaponry? At this stage, Australia is incredibly vulnerable in terms of armed combat. A number of factors with respect to self-reliance must be canvassed in the months, indeed years, ahead. One is the terminology created by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in recent years when he used the word 'clawback' to indicate the return to government on government investments. One can argue quite coherently that if a government spends one dollar in Australia, for example on defence manufacturing, 40c of that is returned to State and Federal governments in direct revenue. That means that the net cost to government, to the people of Australia, is 60c. If we spend a dollar on overseas manufacturing, the eventual cost is more than one dollar by the time we service the overseas debt that involves. But, if we were to say that we would increase our investment in Australia by a billion dollars and have a clawback of $400m, we would be accused by the Opposition, in its opportunistic way, as in the case of Medicare, of inflating revenues and expenditures. How can this nation monitor its investments without the machinery to weigh up and to measure the benefits that accrue from investment in the nation and its future? That particular ingredient should be treated in a much more profound fashion than it has been in the past.

Perhaps a more important aspect of defence manufacturing relates to technology. The major force in world manufacturing technology is defence manufacturing, whether it be the materials, such as carbon fibre composites, titanium metals, miniaturisation, computerisation or transistorisation. Most developments in these areas come from defence-led requirements. Most of the commercial manufacturing taking place in the world is a spin-off and a flow-on from defence manufacturing. The country that gets behind in its defence manufacturing falls behind in world manufacturing export markets. That is exactly the position in which we are. This country is falling further back because it no longer is involved in high skill manufacturing. A self-reliant Australia in the defence field would become a much more competent country and a much more capable exporter of manufactured goods.

The other aspect is the great Australian cringe: If it is Australian made it cannot be very good. I have heard that now for the last two years from departmental personnel and from industry. The deprecation of Australia and Australian industry by Australians is monumental. The corollary is that the Americans are by far the best manufacturers in the defence field. I draw attention to an article in the National Times of 15 to 21 February, part of which states:

The armed services are rejecting shoddy products from military contractors at an unprecedented rate, including fighter jets from McDonnell Douglas, missiles from Hughes Aircraft and semiconductors from Texas Instruments.
And cost increases and cost overruns persist, with inflation in the defence sector running 2 percentage points above the overall inflation rate.

The whole two-page article is about the lack of quality control in American defence manufacturing, yet who in Australia considers that the Americans have quality problems in defence manufacturing? The answer is, no one; after all, it is we who have those problems. This country has to re-establish its capacity and its pride in its skills. The most important single factor leading to the present situation was the election in the mid-1960s when the F111s were a major campaign topic. That purchase was one of the shoddiest tricks played on Australian defence preparedness and one of the most divisive decisions made by government in terms of defence manufacturing. That decision virtually destroyed the aeronautical manufacturing industry in Australia and our capacity to maintain our skill levels in a fast accelerating world competition. It meant that we went back to the Dark Ages, where we have been now for some years.

There is clearly some capacity for the export of defence products. That has a great deal of validity. Certainly, I appreciate the decision of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in recent days to appoint a consultant to examine that issue. But there is perhaps a greater spin-off in terms of export manufacturing. The skills required in a project such as Project Waler-the use of metals, of aluminium and steel, that currently are not used in Australia, the machining tolerances required, the machining skills and design skills required-would be vastly better than those used in work we normally do. The use of higher skills would bring us back to being one of the world's premier metal skills countries.

In the few minutes left to me, I make a call to Ministers of the Government and to the Parliament as a whole to understand and to come to terms with the potential that we have to use our defence expenditure, to integrate it with our industries, and to make it a source of pride to Australians, not just in the political or defence fields, but to the entire Australian community. I make a call to industries to explain to the Australian public how good they are, of what they are capable and what their capacities and skills are, because for many years now they have been badly misrepresented by previous Liberal-Country Party governments which did not see any role for manufacturing in Australia. Our industries are among the best in the world, but to prove that they need to prove their capacity to the Australian people. I am sure that they are prepared to do that.

I make a call also to the service men and women of Australia and point out to them that, by the kind of self-reliant development in which Australians are involved in designing, manufacturing and putting together defence forces that would give us true self-reliance, they can become much prouder of their role in the defence forces. They can have a sense of pride that they are not separate from the community, that they are not using foreign equipment, that they are not beholden to somebody else's training and skill programs or to someone else's manufacturing; they can be proud that their input, as part of the defence of the country, brings the community and industry into one coherent whole. I make those calls on a bipartisan basis because traditionally to some degree there has been a bipartisan view of defence needs. There has not been a bipartisan view of the expression of those needs but certainly there has been in respect of the needs themselves.

In the next few years we have the opportunity to set Australian defence procurement and manufacturing on a course that will see us into early the next century in a way we have not seen since between 1942 and 1946. That is not only possible but also totally desirable. I call on all members of the Parliament in both Houses to look into this area of activity and to try to get behind the call for Australian self-reliance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, at the outset I offer you my congratulations on your re-election. I pick up the point in the Governor-General's Speech which referred to our American relationship, particularly the issue of the ANZUS Treaty. We had an opening debate in this place on Friday on the ANZUS Treaty. It seemed to me that it was appropriate for debate during this session to start with that issue because it is the most important issue facing us, as it affects the security of this country. If one does not have security, if one's borders are not secure, all the welfare and other programs the Left would like to introduce into this country mean nothing. Security is the first and foremost duty of any government. The ANZUS Treaty goes to the heart of the security of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: ANZUS is not an automatic commitment. However, it is a very strong expression of friendship and support by a very major ally of ours. It is a written demonstration that our interests coincide. It is a shield for us in a troubled world-for Australia, for America, to some extent, and for New Zealand, I hope, in due course. It allows us to spend scarce resources on the development of this country. When I hear the naive arguments of members of the Left who want to kick America in the teeth every time they get a chance, I wonder how they would feel if all their fancy programs were abolished and the money for them went into the very necessary defence forces of this country to make ours a credible defence should the ANZUS alliance fall apart. It never ceases to amaze me why the Left wants to see the ANZUS alliance destroyed, why it feels that everything American is bad. The Left makes a lot of noise but it contributes nothing positive to replace what it wishes to pull down. I would have thought that no one was more surprised then the left wing of the Australian Labor Party when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) capitulated two or three weeks ago after a very short campaign by its members.

It is timely to look at why ANZUS is so important to this country. For 34 years it has been a centrepoint of our defence policy-and a very successful one at that-at very little cost to Australia. Obviously the circumstances have changed considerably during those 34 years, but not for the better. The question we have to ask ourselves is whether ANZUS is still relevant. In trying to answer that question it would seem appropriate to look at the area in which we live, at South East Asia, and specifically at Vietnam, to which I have been twice. As people have unkindly said when I went back there last time, at least I got to Hanoi. The Vietnamese expansion should give us very considerable cause for concern. The Vietnamese now firmly occupy not only the whole of Vietnam but also Kampuchea, where they have some 160,000 troops, and Laos, where they could have up to 40,000 troops. Those people who are saying that, given time, the Vietnamese will withdraw from Kampuchea and Laos seem to me to be simply indulging in wishful thinking. From what I saw, I believe that the Vietnamese are there to stay and will never withdraw. Kampuchea and Laos, in due course, if they are not already, will simply become colonies of Vietnam.

That in itself is worrying enough, but the other worrying thing about Vietnam is that it is becoming a massive base for the Russians in South East Asia. Wherever one goes in Vietnam, the Russian presence is overwhelming. In civilian terms, in Vietnam's infrastructure and in its Government's industrial development, the Russian presence is felt. Places such as Cam Ranh Bay and Da-Nang have become massive military bases for the Russian forces. One has to ask why they are there. I am not saying that the Russians are about to invade Australia, but it is certainly not in Australia's interests to encourage the Russian presence in that part of the world.

The Philippines is a highly unstable country. Without putting too fine a point on it, the Marcos Government is in considerable trouble. We do not know what is going to happen in the Philippines in the next few weeks, months or years. However, it is likely that if the increasingly strong insurgent forces succeed in toppling the Marcos Government the very strong American bases in that country will exist no longer. In Papua New Guinea there are increasing problems on the border. The Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) could not even visit the country a week or so ago because his security could not be guaranteed, which is in itself an indictment of the problems in that border area.

In New Caledonia there is a strong dissident group with strong communist affiliations. If that group were to be successful, what would that mean for Australia? Within two hours flying time, for the first time in our history, a hostile nation could be on our doorstep. The ANZUS break-up, if it came to that, would create a general air of uncertainty in the whole Pacific region. All those small countries that look to Australia, New Zealand and America for assistance and guidance would feel uncertain. The umbrella would be removed. Those small countries would be approached by the Russians with offers of industrial and economic development which they may well be tempted to take up. That would be their decision. However, I am saying to the House that it is not in our interests as Australians to allow such a situation to arise. We live in a very troubled area and we would be very stupid not to recognise it.

The main discernible and immediate threat to Australia must be the increasing Russian build-up in this part of the world. Other threats could materialise quickly. When Lord Mountbatten was Chief of Staff of the British forces he was once asked by the Prime Minister of the day how many threats Britain had had to meet in the last few years by the commitment of forces and how many of them had been foreseen. His answer was: 'We have been committed 48 times and we foresaw none of them'. What can happen to Britain can quite easily happen to this country or to any other country.

When we talk about the very real and very big Russian threat that is threatening our interests, all we get from the left wing of the Labor Party is inane chortle, as though the Russians did not exist, as though the problems of Poland and Afghanistan did not exist, as though the Russian presence were just not there. All the time the Left is kicking America in the teeth, the Russians never get a mention. It is as though the balance of power which has maintained the peace for the last 40 years had not been affected, and if the Americans were unilaterally to disarm and we were to dismantle ANZUS everything would be right. Of course nothing could be more stupid than such an attitude.

Let us take a quick look at the Soviet forces in the Pacific. They are not a figment of someone's imagination. These figures one will get from any reputable magazine. The Russian Pacific fleet consists of over 100 submarines, 2 aircraft carriers-

TALK.START.PARA: —Nuclear?

—Nuclear and nuclear-armed. It has 88 principal combat ships, 220 other combat ships and 340 combat aircraft, including 120 bombers. Of those bombers a considerable number are the Bear and Backfire bombers which are capable of covering any part of Australia, including Tasmania, from Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. They are all capable of carrying nuclear weapons. Yet we are faced time and again in the Press by the Left demanding unilateral disarmament.

SPEECH.PARA: Why are the Russians there, why are their numbers increasing and why are they pouring such enormous quantities of arms into South East Asia and the Pacific generally? I do not know the answer to that. However, I know one thing-it is not in Australia's interests to dismantle our defences, to dismantle our alliances while that massive buildup is going on at our doorstep. The fact is that without strong alliances and without American friendship we are very naked indeed.

Let us look quickly at the state of Australia's defences. I think the best word to describe them is 'pathetic'. They are run down and they are suffering a very severe morale problem. They are all short of equipment and most of the equipment is old. They have very limited weaponry and limited-in some cases non-existent-mobility. Despite a lot of talk, in two years nothing has happened to improve that situation. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has charged Mr Paul Dibb with having a good look at our defence forces once again. This is what Mr Dibb had to say to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence about Australia's defences:

Isn't it about time Cabinet asked the Defence Committee to establish what are Australia's vital interests, and what they are in order of priority. Is it the defence of the Australian continent and if so, what parts? Is it the off-shore deposits of oil, natural gas, our territorial seas, our lines of communications? What is the policy? Does it have nothing to do with our neighbouring friendly countries?
Let me tell the House what Mr Dibb had to say about the ANZUS alliance:

The prospect of a breakup of the ANZUS treaty would be of enormous benefit to the USSR's world wide interests. Nothing would be more welcome in Moscow than the dissolution of ANZUS, involving as it does, such close allies of the United States.
When we turn to the terms of reference given to Mr Dibb by the Minister for Defence we read of part of his responsibilities in paragraph 3 (a):
to undertake a review of the content, priorities and rationale of defence forward planning in the light of the strategic and financial planning guidance endorsed by the Government.

I must ask what those guidelines are, because as far as I know they simply do not exist. What the Government is really saying is: 'We don't know what they are. For God's sake, Mr Dibb, tell us'. The Government is asking him to tell it what it should be telling him. That is the reality of Mr Dibb's appointment. It is a classic political ploy to do nothing. There have been studies and reports ad infinitum on the state of Australia's defences. Mr Dibb's appointment is simply to give the Government an excuse further to delay any decisions. We do not want another study, we want some decisions. I do not know Mr Dibb. As far as I know, he is a very able man. All I know is that he will need all his ability if he is to get through any reasonable recommendations and get the Government to act on them.

Let us have a look at what we have got in our defences. The Royal Australian Navy has been reduced to a coastal patrol force. It has three destroyers, four frigates, six destroyer escorts and six submarines. It also has one mine hunter. It has 13 patrol boats armed with 40mm Bofors guns and half-inch machine guns. We have no Fleet Air Arm and our anti-submarine helicopters are based at Nowra. Ours is a Navy without any teeth.

The Army is probably in the most deplorable state of all-a field force under six under-strength battalions. The First Brigade of two battalions in Townsville-the Operational Deployment Force-never has exercised as a complete unit because it does not have the manpower or the support and it has never had the tactical mobility to lift it anywhere, let alone any ground mobility when it gets there. In the last year it has been training on man pack operations because it simply has had no other support.

The Royal Australian Air Force has been given every role that can possibly be conceived. As other defences have been run down the RAAF has been told to take over. Its tasks include air combat, air interception, fighter escort, anti-shipping and close air support of ground forces, and it would be very lucky to do any one of those properly. The F111 squadrons still have iron bombs. At this stage they have no capacity for Harpoon weapons and no capacity for guided bombs. We are getting the F18, which is a magnificent aircraft, but, as I understand it, it has no capacity for aerial refuelling. If we put these squadrons at Weipa, which is the most northerly sealed airstrip from which they can operate in Australia, they could not reach the border of Papua-New Guinea without running out of fuel.
Let me quote briefly what the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence said about Australia's defences:

The Committee considers that Australia's present defence strategy is inadequate in terms of its short term deployment capacity and combat sustainability . . . The Committee is not satisfied that the Australian Defence Force can meet low level threats . . .

It goes on to cite weakness in surveillance, no aerial refuelling, lack of operational readiness, lack of air transport, lack of air defence, lack of modern weapons and so on. That is the opinion of a joint committee of this House.

With such forces and in the face of such a threat, can we afford in this country to stand alone? The answer is no. Therefore, do we need strong alliances, such as the ANZUS alliance? The answer very clearly is yes. The question is how much has the ANZUS alliance been damaged? I was appalled to hear the Minister for Defence in this House the other day make a very pompous and empty speech which did not address the problem at all. The Minister spent all his time denigrating previous governments. He said that the ANZUS issue was:
. . . simply a small episode in the relationship between ourselves and the United States . . .

That, from the Minister for Defence, is abysmal. The damage is that we are seen by the world to have a weak Prime Minister who does not stand for his national interests. He has given encouragement to the Left. I notice some of the questions on the Notice Paper indicate where the Left is going next by simply asking about the contracts for the American bases. That will be the next step. If we cannot help the Americans in simple MX tests, what will happen when it comes to the real crunch? Our intelligence will be curtailed. We are making neighbouring countries nervous. We have exposed our own weak defences in the whole MX issue. We have forced the cancellation of various and valuable exercises. We have invited trade retaliation, and Congressman Cheney has indicated that in the United States of America.
In conclusion, let me read a letter typical of those I have been receiving. It is from a 26-year-old constituent who wrote to me last week as follows:

I am a concerned citizen wishing to let my opinion be known. We need America's backing and we have to be prepared to co-operate with them. I respected Mr Hawke and was glad he was backing the Americans. I am most disappointed he gave in to pressure and backed down.
That sums up the security problems that Australia is facing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks this evening by congratulating you, Madam Deputy Speaker, on your most deserved re-election to your office.

SPEECH.PARA: As many will now be aware, 1985 has been designated as International Youth Year by the United Nations. The theme for the year is participation, development and peace. I believe that it is vital at this early stage that we now look at what we have let ourselves in for. What are we going to do this year? Will we go through a few token events, mouthing patronising platitudes, and forget about it conveniently on 1 January 1986, or will we take the bit between our teeth and work to the spirit of the year to lay the groundwork for participation of young people in our society? I put it to the House that this will require a very broad bipartisan approach at the Federal Government, State government and local government levels and deep into the community as well, if we are to achieve those aims.

Today, I want to concentrate on the participation theme of International Youth Year because the opening of Parliament highlighted to me and to many others the fact that most people have not yet got a clue about what participation of young people in our society is all about and how we are going to improve it. At the swearing in and opening ceremonies of Parliament, I took the liberty of wearing an off-white, light summer suit, cut in the way that young men today would wear their suits.

TALK.START.PARA: —You daring thing!

—That suit did not have a collar such as the honourable member for Warringah would wear, with a noose tied around his neck. It was open. Apart from the fact that the suit got quite a lot of television coverage-which probably points to how boring the opening of Parliament can be-it shows that there is a wide variety of opinion as to whether or not that sort of outfit is bright and modern or shabby and inappropriate. Let us get it straight once and for all. I am not talking as a young person. When one has as much grey hair as I am getting, with what hair is left, one does not really consider oneself biologically youthful. (Quorum formed) I am particularly honoured by the presence of so many of my colleagues in the House. Unfortunately, one does not have to be biologically youthful, as I am not and as most of us are not, to appreciate the adverse reaction to this event and to realise that young people do not relate to this place, with its befuddled and bewigged traditions, and its self-importance which tut-tuts any one who is not in a navy-blue or grey pin-striped suit. Unfortunately, people on the other side of the House distinctly fail to recognise that clothes can be a barrier to the way young people relate to traditions and to institutions such as Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are looking for the participation of young people in the decision-making processes of this country, whether it be in Parliament or in other forms of activity in the community, we, as elderly people-there are not too many people between the ages of 15 and 25 in this House-should be looking at ways in which we can facilitate the involvement of young people in the affairs of this country. What alienates young people from society and the processes which govern them is that society, whether we like it or not, says to young people: 'You are too young to seek your independence. You are too young to have your own opinion. You are too young to know what is best for you, and you are too young to know what is best for this country'. There is no denying that we are reliant on young people for our future, but we create barriers by our 'We know better' attitudes, by our refusal to provide young people with points of access to power, and by our refusal to provide young people with access to decision-making processes and to the status that we reserve for those who fit more into the mainstream of adult society.

At a time when we begin to organise our celebrations of the bicentenary, let us go back more than 2000 years to Socrates, who said: 'The right way to begin is to pay attention to the young'. If one wishes, one may go back a couple of hundred years before that to the sixth century BC and Confucius, who said: 'Youth is to be regarded with respect. How do you know that their futures will not be equal to our present'. Our Australian young people are our future and they are also our today, but today they do not have a real status and a role in our society. Continually we put them into a crossfire situation. Articles such as those which appeared in the Australian recently by Greg Sheridan, attacking the public education system in an hysterical diatribe dressed up as responsible comment, only serve further to destroy the tentative steps of our young people towards adulthood.

Thankfully, today's young people do not consider the paranoid super-powers and their sycophants to be capable of preserving their world for them. They reject the need for a nuclear arsenal that is arrayed before us. I am sorry that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who spoke before me, has left the House, because I am sure he would appreciate the fact that 15,000 times the total explosive and destructive force that was used in World War II, including Hiroshima and Nagasaki, is now sitting in arsenals, nuclear silos and whatever around the world waiting to be rained down upon us. Thankfully, today young people reject the need for that ridiculous arsenal.

Adult society wonders today, and we will be concentrating a lot more of our efforts on wondering, why young people turn to drugs, alcohol, speed and vandalism. The plain truth is that we need to spend more time and money in examining, attacking and eradicating the causes, not just the end results that we see in the smashed telephone box, the drug problem, or the road toll. We have to ask the young people what they think and involve them in the decisions and processes that form part of their own lives.

John Ewen, of the Centre for Youth and Community Studies at Phillip Institute of Technology, which I am proud to say is in my electorate, says his book, 'Youth in Australia-A New Role and a New Deal for the 1980s' makes the point:

The generation of the late sixties took the developed world's leaders by surprise and shook many societies almost to their foundation. Whatever form the next generation's intervention takes (and it could well be one of brute force and violence), it is plain foolishness with a dearth of ideas for progress amongst the tribal elders-that the young should be excluded from the development process. The primary lesson for us from the Third World is that, however difficult and in some cases unsuccessful their youth policies have been, they have started from the objective of offering a role and a status to the young. Youth is not merely a problem to be overcome or controlled, it is an asset to national development to be fostered. Our task is now to investigate how such a policy could be translated and redefined in our society.

Honourable members opposite who now pooh-pooh this should look at what International Youth Year is; that is the whole idea of it. Members of the Opposition have a role to play in this, as well. If they renege on that role, let it be on their heads. The young people today who do not wear the sorts of clothes which our lawyers and business executives wear, who do not care for our stuffy structures or attitudes, will soon be the ones who will be pushing the wheelchairs of honourable members opposite, paying their health and pension benefits and passing laws which will affect all of our lives. Maybe one-day in this very place they will be looking at laws relating to euthanasia, while we wait on our respirators for the outcome.

Nineteen eighty-five is International Youth Year, but that is only a recognition that the future belongs to young people and that young people should be made integral participants in our society today. We are always saying that we are doing this, that or the other for our children's future. This year-the year with the international theme of participation, development and peace-is our chance to provide for our children's future and enhance our own world today. We have to give them now the role and status they seek in their world. We have to give them a go. We have to do our part to take away the barriers of communication. I do not think it should be too hard for members of the Opposition to look at the barriers of communication that exist between old and young. In some ways that may mean that we do not wear ties or regulation shirts, but we must honestly open our doors and our minds to their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—All that today's adult society has managed to do, should you listen to young people, is to have effectively deprived them of a future with peace, jobs and hope. It is very easy for those of us who have jobs, influence and years of building our own individuality and identity to lose sight of what it was like when we were young, when we first left school.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me close with some words from the Costa Rican Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sport in 1981. We pooh-pooh the Third World, we think we are much smarter than its people, but they do have some things which might be of interest and value to us. The Costa Rican Ministry said:

Young people do not want to be classified as adults-to-be, preparing to assume their social responsibilities tomorrow. They want to participate here and now in social life on the same footing as adults.
That has been shown to be the case for Australian young people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois) for having delivered their maiden speeches in this place. I wish them a very fulfilling experience here, if not an enduring one.

SPEECH.PARA: Thursday's outline of the Labor Government's plan or program was a very depressing document indeed for Australian agriculture. In no more than 20 lines and six sentences it dismissed the rural areas of Australia with a talkfest and a year 2000 document. Unless attitudes change, a rural crisis will engulf Australia long before the year 2000. The recent disturbing Budget deficit estimates, the balance of trade deficit and the collapse in the value of the dollar should be a warning to all Australians that our honeymoon is over. They underline the need for responsible responses on the wages and economic management fronts. They point to the need for governments to take the tough decisions. Blow-outs in money supply, sudden reversals in crucial government policies and a wave of crippling industrial disputes have not helped to engender any confidence amongst investors, either in Australia or overseas. Government policies have been the biggest contributor to the decline of the Australian dollar, which has lost 30 per cent of its value against the United States dollar in less than three years, and half of that loss has occurred this month.

The rapid downturn of our economic prospects leaves no other responsible choice to the Hawke Labor Government but to take the hard decisions to reduce public expenditure and to keep wage increases down to the lowest possible levels. No longer can we ignore declining export competitiveness and industry profitability. In heavy overseas borrowing and excessive wage increases, dating back to 1974 when the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, we have seen a successful attempt to trade short term gains in take home pay for declining competitiveness and long term falls in our relative standards of living. Australia is now becoming less able to repay its debts, at a time when those debts are going through the roof. The foreign debt bill has exploded from $40 billion last year to about $60 billion today; more than $10,000 for each Australian family. It is time for a reappraisal of economic policy. Priorities must be changed to maximise real economic growth, raise competitiveness and progressively reduce our accumulated national debt.

The key to economic recovery lies in our ability to maintain and increase export markets for our agricultural, mineral and other export products and services at competitive prices. Only by raising export income will Australia begin to repay its rapidly increasing debt. It should be of great concern that the primary producers have been allowed to slip behind other sectors of the Australian economy. In fact, primary producers will suffer an average 17 per cent cut in income this year as a result of an accelerating cost price squeeze, and sluggish commodity prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was that again?

—A 17 per cent cut. No other sector of the Australian community has had to suffer such a cut. Agriculture today returns an average 2 per cent to capital, which is about 20 per cent of the average level of profitability of other industry sectors, yet primary industry is the first trigger which sparks off an economic chain reaction, undergirding the standard of living of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The dependence of the economy on primary income is the focus of a recent publication, entitled 'Australia and Argentina: On Parallel Paths?' The authors suggest Argentina's slide from wealth reflects the damage caused to primary industry by adverse tax and assistance policies. The end result was a balance of payments crisis for Argentina. These same warning lights are now flashing in Australia, with our trade deficit likely to blow out another $2 billion to an estimated $11 billion or more than 20 per cent, by the end of this financial year.

Commenting on this Australia-Argentina theory in the Sydney Morning Herald on 23 February, Peter Freeman argued that our own economy was less likely to slump due to the strength of a rural sector built on private enterprise and supported by coalition policies over the years. Peter Freeman was courteous enough to ignore the Australian Labor Party; and the farmers know that Party's form only too well. However, the Hawke Labor Government will ignore the importance of rural Australia at its peril and at the peril of every Australian. The Hawke Labor Government must adopt positive economic initiatives which will allow primary industries to maximise their domestic and export potential. For too long governments-State and Federal-and others have regarded farmers as wealthy backwoodsmen whose resources are up for grabs. For too long we have witnessed the successful transfer of resources from rural Australia to other sectors of the economy, including the industrial and public sectors. For too long Australian governments have run away from the challenge of reducing industrial protectionism. In a speech in Japan last year the Prime Minister made the right sounds only to be pulled into gear by the unions. The Hawke Government now has its chance to tackle the level of tariff protection. We must have immediate adjustments to tariff levels or domestic prices will rise and the resulting pressure on the consumer price index will further increase wage rises where there is full indexation under the so-called accord. In short, we risk a new inflationary spiral. The resulting cost pressures will hit primary industry hardest of all as it is the sector least able to pass on cost increases. It is the sector least able to afford cost increases. The Hawke Labor Government must act to remove the devaluation effects from wage adjustments regardless of pressure from its behind-the-scenes master, the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The great feature of a free exchange rate is not only that it has the capacity to keep governments honest-including Treasury and Reserve Bank administrators-but also that it reminds trade union leaders, industrialists, exporters, importers and others of the importance of acting responsibly in the market place in terms of prices and wages. If wage rises outstrip productivity, the resulting inflation further reduces our competitiveness on tough world markets. Of course that leads to further unemployment. Excessive protection encourages irresponsible wage demands and settlements. In reducing protection we must be mindful not only of the low levels of profitability experienced by primary producers but also of the effective rates of assistance to industry at present. Since the start of the last decade, effective assistance to agriculture has been lowered from 28 per cent to 8 per cent, yet manufacturing today continues to enjoy assistance at the rate of 24 per cent, down from 36 per cent over the same period. In other words, the rate of reduction in the level of protectionism has been reduced twice as fast for agriculture as for the industrial sector of the community. We should also be mindful of studies which have drawn a conclusive link between high levels of protection of manufacturing industry and poor manufacturing export performance. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) must act in this area to achieve his stated and commendable goal of boosting our manufacturing export trade but he will not succeed in that objective by picking winners and directing trade resources to those so-called winners.

Despite primary producers' extremely tight margins, they have not sought direct financial aid except in extreme situations where industries face massive short term upheavals resulting from economic difficulties beyond their control. What they seek is stable, predictable government with rational macro-economic policy and a readiness to take the hard options where necessary. There has been massive reconstruction in agriculture in Australia. In the dairy industry, the total number of dairy farmers has dropped from 49,000 to 19,700 since 1964. To counter its problems the industry has after 12 months of exhaustive negotiations developed a national marketing plan acceptable to the vast majority of producers. In a disgraceful show of petty politicking, this plan has been rejected at three meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council by the Victorian Labor Government.

Although the industry has undergone reconstruction further problems face the industry due to the huge dairy stockpiles resulting from European Economic Community and United States subsidy policies. The Victorian and Federal Labor governments should stand condemned for the obstruction to the implementation of a modified national plan which has been thrashed out by the various dairy groups in the States. There is absolutely no justification for any attempt by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to impose an alternative plan based on the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations which are rejected by most sections of the industry.

The self-help dairy industry plan, as with most current rural industry proposals, would have little impact on government outlays. By contrast, there are occasions when economic events outside the control of the industry threaten short term, but devastating, social damage to whole communities. In those circumstances short term aid is justified, if not essential. The highly efficient sugar industry faces such a crisis today because of the huge subsidised surplus of sugar from EEC countries being dumped at give-away prices.

The industry is making every effort to produce a scheme for long term self-rationalisation, but in the meantime faces a 1985 No. 1 pool price of $230 a tonne, which will barely cover costs. In 1986, the pool price is likely to drop to about $180, and in 1987 it will be around $140 to $160. By guaranteeing a minimum average price of $240 a tonne the Government would at least offer the efficient producers a chance to remain in the industry. Temporary assistance would be only a marginal recompense to an industry which has subsidised Australian consumers to the net value of more than $300m over the past decade.

To fail the sugar industry at this time is to fail the most efficient sugar industry in the world to the advantage of heavily subsidised beet growers in Europe. At two elections the Hawke Labor Government has promised assistance and then walked away from its commitment. A maximum $16.5m has been forthcoming from the Federal Government, while the Queensland Government has contributed more than $30m over the same period to bridge the industry over this difficult crisis. The inadequate contribution of the Hawke Labor Government to date makes a mockery of the Prime Minister's assurances to the industry in Brisbane a week before the last election to 'undertake a financial commitment . . . which is going to result in a strong and viable industry'.

The steel industry in Australia three years ago was receiving average effective aid for a range of products of 14 per cent. The Government's steel industry plan has raised bounties from $1m in 1982-83 to an estimated $52m this financial year. If it is good enough for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, with its approximately 29,000 employees in the steel division, in its hour of need, it is good enough for Australia's 20,000 workers directly employed in the sugar industry and another 100,000 whose jobs indirectly depend on the industry. That sort of assistance should be good enough for an industry which earned $617m in export income in 1983 and more than $1 billion two years earlier.

The future of all Australian primary industry lies largely in external markets. Most of our industries are highly efficient and able to supply domestic orders and have a capacity to produce at a relatively low cost increasing volumes for export. However, the subsidy policies of Europe are blocking efficient lower cost food production with their high cost subsidised surpluses. The Opposition was pleased that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry responded to calls by farm groups to visit the EEC personally and explain to the new Commission our traditional markets, especially in the Asian-Pacific Basin. However, there remains some uncertainty over what was achieved in those talks and whether guarantees were in fact watertight. It is essential, therefore, that the Minister for Primary Industry report to this Parliament as soon as possible on the outcome of their negotiations. To delay this report will only heighten the uncertainty now confronting producers, especially those engaged in our vital beef trade on dwindling Asian-Pacific basin markets. We must not have a repeat of the Prime Minister's refusal to make such a report following his February Asian tour last year.

There is one other aspect of Government policy which will be crucial to the future, not only of primary industry but of all industries in our economy and the people of this country. They must be confident that they have stable, responsible Federal government which is committed to national macro-economic policies and concerned to improve our competitiveness and trade performance. Sadly, the events of the past few weeks indicate otherwise. The MX missile fiasco was one of the most disastrous foreign policy moves ever undertaken by an Australian Prime Minister. It seems incredible that the Prime Minister of Australia should have been forced to make a panic decision to break an agreement with the United States while on foreign soil but only a day away from his official visit to the United States. Surely if he had to make a backdown to his faction-riddled Labor Party he should have continued his visit to the United States where he could have had a full, frank discussion with President Reagan explaining the reasons why he, as Prime Minister of Australia, had to break an undertaking given in 1983.

The repudiation of his agreement with the United States is a major victory for the socialist Left of the Labor Party. It is a major victory for the Soviet Union and its communist allies. The majority of Australians have every reason to be disappointed, if not devastated, over the apparent weakness of the Prime Minister in backing down to members of his radical Left and their fellow travellers of the Centre Left. If this can happen in a policy area as important and fundamental as our alliance with the United States, it could happen to any Labor policy. The devastation of confidence at home and overseas has been clearly reflected in the fortunes of the dollar.

In conclusion, I call on the Hawke Labor Government to give clear, unequivocal commitments to the primary industries of Australia and then to carry through those commitments. The farm costs summit, the tax summit and the 'Year 2000' report will all give the Hawke Labor Government an important opportunity to establish the needs of the rural sector and to act on those needs. On the other hand, it cannot use those reviews as a shield behind which to hide a lack of substantial policy. It must recognise the rightful place of the primary sector in the Australian economy as a first step to recovering some of the ground that has been lost. It must recognise that there is a crisis in the dairy, sugar, dried fruits and rice industries with wheat, grain, sheep meat, and other industries not far behind. There is a crisis of confidence in agricultural Australia and action must be taken right now to ensure that agriculture does not crash in Australia as it has done in Argentina.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I congratulate you, Madam Deputy Speaker, on your re-election as Chairman of Committees. Like other speakers, I welcome that move. In particular I congratulate my colleagues, the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois), who moved and seconded this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there is some restraint on the Government side I would like to touch on some of the major issues facing us today and look at some of our achievements in the past. Firstly, let us look at the Government's record. It is hard to believe that, just about two years ago, our economy was in recession and we were losing 200,000 jobs a year. Yet here we are, two years later, with one of the fastest growing economies in the world. We have a significant growth in employment and in other areas of the economy. The level of unemployment is down from 10.3 per cent to 8.1 per cent. As I said earlier, unemployment was growing under a conservative government. That is one of the major reasons why the former conservative Government was defeated at the polls in 1983. It is also one of the major reasons why it was not elected again in December 1984.

Back in 1977 the conservatives promised to lower housing interest rates by 2 per cent. They put housing interest rates up by 5 per cent. That is another reason why they were not re-elected in 1984. On the other hand, this Government has been able to bring down housing interest rates. That has been of great advantage to a lot of young people in Australia, particularly those who are buying homes. We have reduced the inflation rate from 11.5 per cent to 6.1 per cent. Back in 1975, after the Whitlam Government was sacked, the conservative Government of the day said that one of its major tasks was to reduce inflation. We had seven years of conservative government. The conservative Government had seven years in which to reduce that inflation rate, yet when it was kicked out of office, as it rightly was, the inflation rate was still the same as it was when it took office. We have reduced that inflation rate to 6.1 per cent and it will probably drop lower next year.

We have had the fewest industrial disputes in 16 years. Let us cast our minds back to how things were prior to 1983. We have only to look at the Queensland dispute to be reminded. The Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, took on the unions and, in the process of trying to win that dispute, was willing to sacrifice the benefits and the welfare of the people of Queensland to get his own way. It is only because of the responsibility of the unions that those people have acceded to the request to go back to work, but that dispute is not over. We can see what will happen. We will have the old confrontation with Australian against Australian-in this case Queenslander against Queenslander-trying to get some political advantage. I have been told that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen was trying to go to the polls. That is well and truly out of the way now because there was a significant swing against his Party in the by-election, and so there should be. That is what the people of Queensland think about the confrontationist style of the Queensland Government. That is what the people in Australia think about the confrontationist style of honourable members opposite. In our first term we introduced the first home owners scheme, which has meant assistance for 75,000 young Australians, many of whom could not have got into their first homes if it were not for that scheme.

I turn now to the tax summit which is to be held in July. That tax summit is long overdue. It does not matter to whom we talk in Australia, everyone says that we have one of the worst taxation systems in the world. It is a taxation system which moved Professor Mathews a few years ago to say-I cannot remember his exact words, but they went something like this: 'It is not a matter of making the rich pay more tax; it is a matter of making the rich pay any tax at all'. That is the taxation system we have now. Let us hope that the taxation summit coming up in July will address those problems. Under the Liberal Party of Australia we had massive tax avoidance and that is continuing today. We presented tax legislation five times and we will present it again. I say to the new members in this place: 'If you want to be counted as friends of the tax avoiders, you will have your chance pretty soon'. Not only members of the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party deserve censure; members of the Democrats are the people who really deserve censure because they are the people who come into these Houses of Parliament and say to the people of Australia that they will keep the politicians honest. If there is a group of politicians more dishonest than the National Party, and that is saying something, it is the Democrats.

Let us look at the reliance that has been placed on income tax through the years. For the last six years, from the time we started collecting taxes to the present time, this country has relied on income tax. How easy it is for the people of wealth and people who are privileged to get out of receiving taxable income and paying their taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

SPEECH.PARA: I was in the House the other day when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) presented some of his Bills. One of them was to do with tax trust stripping. I will read his words to the Parliament tonight:

Mr Speaker, trust stripping involves arrangements under which trust income is formally allocated for tax purposes to a beneficiary that does not pay tax on it-such as a tax exempt charitable institution. The income concerned, however, is effectively retained-undiminished by the payment of tax-by those family members really intended to benefit from it.

I asked myself: Who are the people who really look at these schemes? Is it the average worker on pay as you earn tax? Of course not. It is the people of privilege, the people who can afford to pay highly priced accountants and lawyers to go into these schemes. These are the sorts of things this Government has a clear mandate to stamp out and it is going to do it.

Perhaps the most important thing we have to do is tackle unemployment. It is the worst social problem we have today. It did not come about only in the period of less than two years that this Government has been in power. Unemployment did not happen just because the Hawke Labor Government was elected in March 1983. It is a compounding of events and of decisions not taken in the past. The 1960s and 1970s were the years of lost opportunity in this country. Decisions on restructuring should have been made then but were not. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, effectively sums up the situation when he says that anybody who really wants to look at a working museum should look at Australian industry. One of the things we have to do as a government is train our young people and teach them skills. It is of no use to give them the dole as that will not do a thing for young people. Leaving them with no skills at all makes them unemployable. One of the first things we have to do is train those young people. This is something the previous Government never addressed and it is something that this Government has to address. I am pleased to say the some of the committees on which I serve are looking at that particular problem now. Not only does training give people a greater advantage in getting a job, but also it gives them a bit of self-esteem and allows them, if they can, to start up their own industries. If a person has skills he can start doing things; if he has no skills, he is unemployable. Members of the Opposition get up and give notice of silly motions, as they did today, and talk about industrial relations, employment and getting people back to work, but they did absolutely nothing when they were in government. Madam Deputy Speaker, like you, I was shocked when 600,000 of our citizens did not have their votes counted in the last election. Certainly one of the cornerstones of any democracy is having a system whereby all voters have their votes counted.
