Let me turn to Medicare. This is the second time that the Australian electorate has given the Australian Labor Party Government a clear mandate for Medicare. What do we have in New South Wales? The only thing that the Federal Government understood was someone standing with one foot on their throats and kicking their private parts with the other . . .

I would like to close on a matter which I think this Parliament should address in its current term; that is, the glaring gap in Australia's provision for its retired. This Government, in its first term, tried to do something about the retirement system, inadequate as it is. Firstly, we put a lump sum on taxation payments. It seemed to us that double dipping was not fair. A person could go through his working life and get a taxation benefit for, rightly, putting some of his resources away to look after himself when he was retired. We gave a taxation incentive for that and I am not knocking it. What I am knocking is the practice of taking the lump sump and paying virtually no tax-around about one per cent in tax on the lump sum-and then investing it in such a way that one did not get an income so that one could then go back to the taxpayers and say: 'How about giving us a pension?' What did the Opposition do then? Was any responsibility shown? No. The main group of people who attacked that-this is a good barometer of what the Government is all about-were among the most privileged groups in our society, the airline pilots. They took lump sum payments of about $600,000, having worked 38 hours a month and earned about $75,000 a year. They are the people who really got stuck into the Government on that matter. To me that is a clear statement that we were right.

The Government also brought in the assets test. A number of honourable members on that side of the House-the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) is not one of them-can thank their lucky stars that they are here today, because the advertising campaign in the election period by the Opposition parties was nothing more than scandalous on that issue. They did nothing more than try to scare the pensioners, and they did that. They scared the pensioners who came running to my office. I am sure other members of the Government experienced the same thing. People were scared out of their wits by propaganda put out by the Liberal Party of Australia. Why can it not fight an election fair and square? Why does it not get out and tell the truth? A number of honourable members opposite-I am sure the honourable member for Wide Bay is one of them-did not do that.

This country is lucky that it has returned this Government. We have the best Prime Minister, certainly in my lifetime. We have the best Ministry to sit in this House since the Second World War, and that is an independent statement. We have the best back bench, and if that is being a bit indulgent I will wear it. We have the best Government that this country has had for a while. It is a government which will not shirk its responsibilities and which will take the tough decisions that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) talked about. Members of the previous Government did nothing in the time they were in office. That is why they are in opposition and will be there for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: Election day-1 December 1984-marked the beginning of the end of the Hawke socialist Government. This discredited, dishonourable government is now in its second and final term of office. The current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the little Caesar of Australian politics, has lost his charisma and does not know where to find it. He is on the way out. We now have a minority government in office in Australia. According to the latest Morgan Gallop Poll only 43 per cent of Australians would vote for the Hawke socialist Government today. If an election had been held just nine days ago the Leader of the Opposition, Andrew Peacock, would be Prime Minister of Australia and the present temporary occupant of the Lodge would have been told to pack his bags and be on his way.

The people of Australia are not fools, Mr Deputy Speaker. They started to see through this phoney Prime Minister late last year and if the Federal election had been held a week or two later there is no doubt in my mind, and in the minds of many long term parliamentary commentators in this place, that Prime Minister Hawke would have got the axe. As it is, there is now considerable speculation on whether he will survive as Prime Minister for the full term of the Thirty-fourth Parliament. The knives are out and there is no doubt that he will have to perform an extraordinary juggling feat between the lunatic factions of his coalition Government if he is to be in the Lodge for Christmas dinner in 1985.

The Hawke socialist Government is a coalition of lunatic factions. We have the socialist Left or, as it is more properly described, the pro-communist Left. We have the Centre Left whatever that might mean; we have the so-called Right, which is truly the sanitised Left in anybody's language; we have the independents who are nevertheless bound to throw overboard their 'independence' whenever Caucus makes a decision; and lastly, we have the biggest faction of all and that is the 'Left-out group' which, of course, comprises all those talented people who once again have been left out of the Ministry. One has only to study the faces of honourable members sitting on the benches in this chamber occupied by the Hawke socialist Government to realise quickly that there is more talent outside the Ministry than there is inside it. Yet the Prime Minister had the gall to try to con the people of Australia by telling them that this was the most talented Ministry since World War II. What a lot of piffle! What a lot of hogwash! The combined talents of the Hawke socialist Government Ministry would be hard pressed to exceed the mental capacities of the fourth graders of whom the Treasurer (Mr Keating) spoke so feelingly just a couple of weeks ago. I put it to the House that every fourth grader attending school in Australia today should feel insulted that he or she has been compared with any member of the Hawke socialist Government.

This deceitful Government conned its way into power on 5 March 1983 and escaped by a whisker the executioner's axe on 1 December 1984. A Government which has earned acknowledgement in the Guinness Book of Records as having broken more promises and in a shorter time than any other Government in the history of western parliamentary democracies now pledges, without any hope at all of honouring its solemn promises, a magical, mythical, mystical economic trilogy. It had the hide to reaffirm it as recently as last Thursday in the extraordinary speech which it gave to His Excellency the Governor-General of Australia who was required by law to read it at the opening of the Thirty-fourth Parliament. I will quote the speech verbatim; this is what it said:

The Government has given the people of Australia explicit commitments regarding the Budget deficit, Budget expenditures and taxation. None of these will be increased as a proportion of gross domestic product in 1985-86 and over the Government's second term.

Those commitments which the Prime Minister and the Hawke socialist Government obliged His Excellency to read on 21 February simply cannot be honoured. It is as plain as that. This economic trilogy trumpeted around Australia by the Prime Minister did not even have the backing of Cabinet. Any matriculation economics student in the land could see that this Government, the biggest spending, highest taxing peacetime Government Australia has ever known simply cannot implement the programs and policies upon which it has been elected and at the same time contain the Budget deficit, Budget expenditures and taxation. Somebody will have to pay the bill.

The people of Australia have already been victims of the biggest tax slug since World War II in the 24 months that the Hawke socialist Government has been in power. Today, an average worker is paying $23.50 a week more in taxes under Prime Minister Hawke than he or she paid under Prime Minister Fraser. The increase in personal income tax receipts in the first 15 months of the Hawke socialist Government exceeded substantially the highest tax grab during any period of the Whitlam socialist Government and that was the Government which brought Australia to the brink of bankruptcy in the dark years of 1972 to 1975.

Quite bluntly, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Hawke socialist Government is more dangerous to the future of Australia than the Whitlam socialist Government ever was and, heaven knows, it was bad enough. In economic terms this Government is a disaster and, mark my words my fellow Australians, each and every one of us will have to pay a pretty hefty bill when the discredited Hawke socialist Government is thrown out of office at the next Federal election, as it undoubtedly will be. However, it is also clear in other areas that the Prime Minister and this Government are simply unfit for office. They cannot be entrusted with the national security of Australia.

Any person who listened to the debate in this House last Friday would have quickly realised that the Hawke socialist Government, and particularly its erratic and emotional leader-some would say hysterical-have betrayed Australia's interests in the international scene. The ANZUS Treaty fiasco of recent weeks has done more to damage the national security of Australia than anything else since World War II. For this to occur in peacetime is an appalling indictment of a Prime Minister who was prepared to put appeasement of party factions ahead of national interest. As the Leader of the Opposition so eloquently stated on Friday, this is a Government whose actions in recent times have done enormous damage to the ANZUS alliance. I can see no difference in principle between the actions of Comrade Lange and his Government and the actions of Prime Minister Hawke and the Hawke socialist Government. I am absolutely convinced that the United States will never be able to trust the word of Australia while the Hawke socialist Government remains in office.

We now see publicly exposed a Prime Minister who has let his country down. Quite bluntly, we now have a situation in which a second grade Prime Minister has tried to turn this great country-Australia-into a third world country in response to the urgings of fourth graders and fifth columnists. That is what the Government has done. The Prime Minister's recent visit to the United States was a disaster of unparalleled proportions. The headlines of the United States Press tell it all. Listen to this, Mr Deputy Speaker: 'Australia balks on accord to aid in U.S. test of MX'; 'Premier cites split in Party'-that was on the front page of the New York Times-'Australian takes middle position in the U.S.-New Zealand dispute'-

TALK.START.PARA: —What paper?

—That was in the New York Times which is read by millions of our allies. What is worse, in a feature article, Bernard Gwertzman, a leading American writer-this was read by millions of Americans-states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke sought to put himself in a middle position between Australia's two allies in the alliance.

In the same article Gwertzman quotes a senior State Department official as saying that the United States no longer viewed New Zealand as 'a loyal and faithful ally'. If that is the judgment on New Zealand right now, what do honourable members think is the judgment on Australia under this erratic, emotional and hysterical Prime Minister and this dangerous, sinister Hawke socialist Government? It is no wonder that Republican Senator William S. Cohen and Congressman Robert Cheney, across party lines, united with Democrat Congressman Stephen J. Solarz, Chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Asian Sub-Committee, in expressing their outrage.

When I read in the New York Times that 'Australia's Prime Minister said today that he had told the United States that because of a revolt in his own Party he would probably have to renege on a pledge', I, as an Australian, feel ashamed. In the same report it is stated that Prime Minister Robert Hawke 'startled American officials'. The latest public opinion polls show that the Prime Minister also succeeded in startling a very large number of Australians. I put it to the Prime Minister that he has let us down and has let Australia down. He can never again be entrusted with the sacred duty of guarding the defence of this nation.

The greatest paradox of this entire disaster-this international tragedy of giant proportions-is that Mr John Curtin, whom the Prime Minister eulogises, and President Franklin D. Roosevelt created in the darkest days of World War II an alliance which has now tragically been destroyed by two socialist Prime Ministers, the Prime Minister of Australia and the Prime Minister of New Zealand. The Tasman Sea between Tasmania and New Zealand is no longer the subject of Western alliance naval surveillance. The Royal Australian Navy is incapable of patrolling the area, the Royal New Zealand Navy is absolutely tiny and the United States cannot-I repeat cannot-patrol the area without access to New Zealand ports. History will judge that ANZUS was destroyed in 1985. Australia is the poorer as a direct result of the actions of the present Prime Minister and his Government and their capitulating to the pro-communist Left.

We in Tasmania feel particularly vulnerable about the situation in the Tasman Sea. The plain fact is that the Tasman Sea, an enormous expanse of water between, on the one side, Tasmania and south-east mainland Australia-I see present in the chamber all the members from Tasmania, as they always are-and New Zealand and extending from New Caledonia south to the southern oceans adjoining Antarctica, as a direct result of the actions of comrade Lange and Prime Minister Hawke, has now become a Soviet maritime playground.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The honourable member for La Trobe can laugh. He is one of the fourth graders. I am surprised that so many of them got back from the Soviet Embassy dinner to be here tonight. They wear a track from here to the Soviet Embassy.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. We were not at the Soviet Embassy tonight; I do not know what the honourable member is talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: We must be the greatest fools in the world if we fail to recognise that, in the eyes of the Soviets, Australia is the richest prize-I emphasise that-in this region of the world. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your position in the chair. I am also pleased to have the opportunity to congratulate the Speaker and Madam Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees for the exemplary performance they gave in the last Parliament. Of course, that is the reason they have been re-elected to this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been occasions when the Speaker and Deputy Speaker have had to admonish me for making interjections. I must admit it has not happened very often, but there have been occasions when speeches such as the one that has just been given by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) have provoked one to make interjections. I do not think that I have ever heard a speech in which the speaker has so indulged himself in kicking the communist can. I thought that sort of thing went out years ago, but the honourable member for Denison has to continue it because nothing else in his speech was worth repeating or mentioning. I prefer therefore to get on with my speech and make no more comments about the honourable member for Denison.

At the declaration of the poll for the seat of La Trobe last December, I emphasised that the three main policy areas which would be my main concerns during my third term as the member for La Trobe would be unemployment, poverty and nuclear disarmament. I thank the electors of La Trobe for their strong confidence in me which enables me to represent them and allows me to deal with these most important and vital issues.

In speaking in the debate on the Address-in-Reply, I wish to concentrate on these three vital issues which our Government and, indeed, the whole world are facing, and which were also mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech. With regard to unemployment, the Governor-General said:
The Government remains deeply concerned at the disproportionate share of unemployment which is borne in Australia by young people.
In relation to poverty, the Governor-General said:
In its coming term the Government will continue to give a high priority to improving the living standards of the most needy in the community.
Finally, in relation to nuclear disarmament, the Governor-General said:

The Government remains deeply committed to advancing the cause of peace, arms control and disarmament . . . It will actively promote programs for the International Year of Peace in 1986, and will advance the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Proposal.

My concern is that the Government has not given sufficient recognition to the fact that one of the main causes of unemployment and poverty is the ever increasing economic cost of the nuclear arms race, which involves particularly the economic resources of the two super-powers. These resources, which could be diverted to productive employment and the alleviation of poverty, are being used in the development of first strike nuclear weapons systems, such as killer satellites and the MX missile which has been grossly misnamed the 'Peacemaker' by President Reagan. The United States has had record budget deficits over the past four years. This year the deficit is expected to reach $US220 billion. These deficits have arisen largely because of the huge cost of armaments programs. It is this huge deficit, with its voracious appetite for funds, which has caused the sharp rise in interest rates in all the countries of the world which are strongly tied to the international financial system, including Australia.

Apart from the difficulties of expanding Australia's manufacturing capacity on the basis of dear money, high interest rates cause hardship to home buyers and help to fuel inflation. They also cause problems in relation to our total foreign debt which has multiplied by three times over the past four years. We now owe $42,000m, which is equal to nearly one-quarter of our gross domestic product, and the cost of servicing these debts in terms of interest payments was $3.1 billion or 11 per cent of our export earnings. If we add to that figure the repayment of capital we reach a total annual repayment of foreign debt at $7.7 billion in 1983-84, which the Reserve Bank has stated is 28 per cent of our export receipts.

As I have mentioned, high interest rates are restrictive of increased business activity which means less employment and more poverty. Nowhere is this more evident than in many Third World countries, where unemployment and poverty have been made catastrophically severe by years of drought. The unfortunate mixture of high foreign debt and high unemployment levels has led many people to predict that Australia will become a Third World economy by the end of the century. I do not hold such a pessimistic view myself, as I anticipate that Federal Labor governments will stay in office for many years to come. Nevertheless, it is imperative for Australia to re-structure industry to provide more employment and to improve our export capacity. The recently completed Ferris report on export marketing has called for increases in our exports of manufactured goods and services on the basis of wide-ranging export incentives. In this respect it is particularly disappointing to hear reports that the Industries Assistance Commission has failed to support the industry development plan of the Amalgamated Metals Foundry and Shipwrights Union. The plan was essentially one which advocated import replacement policies leading to an increase of between 238,000 to 293,000 jobs in a five to seven year period, and was supported with contributions from both the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research and the Victorian Ministry of Employment and Training.
In the Governor-General's Speech, it was stated that:
The Government remains committed to developing a strong and competitive manufacturing industry.

It is mainly as a result of competition from East Asian countries, especially Japan, that our metals and engineering industries have suffered a severe decline over the past ten years, resulting in a net loss of 152,000 jobs. The AMSFU plan indicates how Japanese manufacturers are strongly assisted by financial support from the Japanese Government. It is essential that the Federal Government adopt similar policies to support our own metals and engineering industries. These industries are vitally important for support because they employ a very skill-intensive work force which provides technological opportunities for the remainder of the economy. The AMSFU plan outlines policies which could be implemented by the Government to assist Australian manufacturers in producing quality manufactured goods for the Australian domestic market.

With the expansion of our manufacturing capacity would come a first phase of increased technological efficiency. Following this phase would come a planned second phase of export growth whereby Australian Companies compete directly with East Asian manufacturers. The third phase would be essentially one of a withdrawal of government financial support.

It is important, in my view, for the Government to resist pressures to allow so called market forces to dictate the process of structural change in the manufacturing industry. One of the strong advocates of a market-led structural change is the Industries Assistance Commission. However, officers of the Commission appear to overlook the fact that countries such as Japan pay lip service to the concept of an open and liberal international trading system whilst at the same time providing government export incentives to assist the international competitiveness of their export industries. Of course, Australian Government financial support should only be provided on the basis of certain fundamental principles. The AMSFU plan sets out six major principles. Firstly, there must be accountability by the companies operating under the industry development plan as industry assistance must not be open ended and must be subject to adequate performance. Secondly, there must be compensation for existing export industries whose competitiveness is reduced by the operation of an industry development plan. Thirdly, information must be provided in full to support the selection of industries for assistance. Fourthly, representation must be available for all the interested groups involved including unions, consumers, management and government. Fifthly, there must be flexibility in the management of industry development programs and the use of policy instruments, such as investment incentives, taxation and research assistance, skill and re-training programs, industry mergers or co-operative agreements, foreign investment controls, export incentives, bounties and subsidies. These policy instruments must be integrated with specific policies of export expansion, import replacement and industry modernisation.

Finally, there must be co-ordination between the different levels of policy development and implementation to ensure that Government resources are used both flexibly and efficiently. In my view, the AMSFU industry development plan is one of the most constructive job creation proposals to emerge from the prices and incomes accord. The Federal Government will be failing the union movement and the hundreds of thousands of unemployed workers if it does not support the plan.

In reality, we no longer live today in a market system. The international capitalist economy of which Australia is a part is dominated by a few powerful interest groups, concentrated in a privileged relationship between big business and governments. The prices and incomes accord has made it clear that unions can no longer deal within a framework of traditional collective bargaining on wages and working conditions, but must also take part in a system of social accounting.

Social accounting requires that multinational corporations as well as governments provide information on their forward plans and on their impact on what is done, why, where and when in the economy. Such a planning process is a challenge to the union movement, but in the case of the metal trades unions they have not hesitated to take up their responsibilities with the submission of their industry development plan. I congratulate them on their initiative, and trust that the Federal Government will seriously consider the plan despite the reported adverse reaction of the Industries Assistance Commission.

In the short time given to me to speak on the Address-in-Reply I will not be able to deal with all aspects of the Governor-General's Speech. However, I will make some comments on the Government's major review of the Australian tax system which the Governor-General announced will take place in 1985. Caucus members are anticipating that, in line with other representatives of the Australian people, they will have the opportunity to participate in the national tax summit to be held next July. I hope to make my own contribution to the tax summit, although in a spirit of co-operation my contribution probably will become part of a broad approach by a group of Caucus members.

I believe that if we are ever to achieve a more equitable distribution of wealth in Australia-at present 10 per cent of the population own 60 per cent of the country's total wealth and 50 per cent of the population own less than 8 per cent of the country's wealth, or the richer 2,000 Australians own as much as the present two and a half million Australians own-we must then introduce an effective tax on wealth. Unfortunately, the wealth distribution figures I have cited relate to 1981 as no up to date figures are available. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has indicated, however, that an inquiry into the distribution of wealth in Australia will be undertaken shortly, which will indicate, I forecast, that the rich have become richer and the poor poorer in the four years since 1981.

For the record, I indicate my opposition to any broadly-based indirect tax, although the introduction of new narrow based indirect taxes should be investigated. The reason for my opposition to the introduction of a broadly based indirect tax is that such a tax would fall inexorably on the poorer sections of the population. I favour the introduction of a capital gains tax which member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the United States of America have incorporated in their taxation systems. I also support the introduction of gift taxes and an inheritance tax, which should be imposed on the heirs of wealthy estates.

Finally, the introduction of a net annual tax on the assets of the rich should, together with the other taxes I have mentioned, provide substantial government revenues. The Government could then provide income tax relief for low income earners by substantially raising the tax-free threshold. I commend the Government for its aim of creating a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australian society.

Before I end, I congratulate all those new members who have been elected to this Parliament and, in particular, the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois), who delivered their maiden speeches in the Parliament this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset, like all the previous speakers in this Address-in-Reply debate and certainly none the less sincerely, through you, I congratulate Mr Speaker on his re-election to high office by this House, Madam Deputy Speaker on her re-election as Chairman of Committees and you and your colleagues on your appointment as Deputy Speakers in this chamber. Secondly, I address some personal remarks to my friends and supporters in the electorate of Tangney. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is not my maiden speech, I have been here previously. I address some remarks specifically to those friends and supporters who stood by me during my 20 months out of this chamber. In my view, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) saw the writing on the wall. I regret that he did not stay on for the fight. Nevertheless, to all of those friends and supporters who worked with me, part time for some 16 months and full time in so many cases for some four months, go my heartfelt thanks. Our Liberal campaign in Tangney recorded a 6.3 per cent swing in our favour. That is noted by some commentators as a national high. To all of those who know to whom I am speaking-they will, of course, be reading this speech in the future-I simply say thank you very much.

SPEECH.PARA: I now intend to dwell briefly on some matters relating to my portfolio, the portfolio for which I have been given shadow ministerial responsibility in opposition-that of employment, industrial relations and youth affairs. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you judge my speech to be somewhat sober it is because events have cast it so. I have returned to the Parliament after a short break. I judge that I return at a time when the Australian economy, and consequently our society, is at a crossroads and I have absolutely no faith in this Government's ability to pursue the right path. I say that not out of blind pessimism nor simply our of partisan political loyalties, for increasing numbers of the Australian electorate hold the same view and many more are on the verge of embracing it.

The Government, for its part, has asked us to believe that it has a special relationship with the trade union movement-special in the sense of positive, constructive, even unique. The Government has argued that this special relationship has exceptional benefits for our country, particularly through the apparent minimisation of industrial conflict that it maintains has occurred. It is true that the Hawke Government's first term was blessed by relative industrial peace. But to what extent was this due to the Government's supposed special relationship with the trade union movement? One asks oneself to what extent it was promoted and maintained by the accord. Could it not have been due, in part at least, to high levels of unemployment? Could it not have been due, in part at least, to some promises made before the election we have just gone through? These are the questions that media commentators are only just now beginning to ask. They are beginning to ask them because the reality is starting to catch up with the myth.

Myths are functional. In traditional societies they are often used to communicate moral tales or to portray desirable models of behaviour. They generally inculcate individual members of society with necessary group norms. For a myth to survive it must be plausible, it must contain a kernel of truth and it must possess some social utility. Otherwise the myth perishes. It is simply forgotten, its plausibility stretched too far or its usefulness outlived. The myth of this Government's special relationship with the trade union movement is a modern instance. It is no longer plausible. If it is no longer plausible, it no longer has utility and will quickly perish. We are now witnessing around us the beginning of the death of this myth, presided over by the media but ultimately executed by the people of Australia.

For it is the people who are now saying that the accord no longer accords with reality. It is the people who are questioning the existence of a special relationship, other than perhaps one of extreme vulnerability on the Government's part to trade union pressure. After all, the Government's second term, not even three months old, has seen many industrial disputes already. There has been the Public Service dispute, which has helped sink the Australian dollar; which has tied up untold goods on our wharves, goods necessary for further production; which has cost the taxpayers millions of dollars in interest charges because of the Government's forced borrowings to stay afloat, to stay solvent; and which will cost taxpayers yet more if public servants are awarded a wage rise in excess of consumer price index linked rises awarded at the national wage hearing. After all, it is we, the Australian people, taxpayers, who pay the wages of public servants, and we will pay to foot this bill.

Another dispute is the continuing Builders Labourers Federation fiasco, replete with the stench of high thuggery, standover tactics and worse. This Government has refused even to follow the example of deregistration set by Premier Wran in New South Wales. The Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen strike in the Hunter Valley is crucifying the remnants of our reputation as a reliable coal supplier and is enhancing the prospects for further lay-offs in the New South Wales coalfields. Strife on the waterfront with the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and the Seamen's Union of Australia holding up goods on our wharves and ships in our ports around Australia is in response to employers exercising their legal rights in courts.

I have enumerated only some of the major disputes. They are symbols, prominent surface expressions of a much deeper unrest, a general unrest which statistics are now beginning to bear out. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on industrial disputation in Australia show an overall increase in the number of strikes in 1984 compared with those in 1983. Figures for 1985 have already had a big boost from the disputes that I have outlined, not to mention the lesser known regional disputes which are breaking out all over the country-in Canberra, in the Pilbara and on the Melbourne waterfront. The Public Service unions' attitude and approach are indicative. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission did not give them what they wanted, so they implemented bans. Those bans had such serious and far-reaching effects that not a single Australian failed to be affected by them in some way or another. The bans were effective. The Government rewarded the Public Service unions' militancy by leaning on the Arbitration Commission to re-open the case. The unions may still get a wage rise over and above that flowing from the national wage case, despite the Arbitration Commission's clear rejection of the unions' original arguments.

No action or decision in our industrial relations system is taken in isolation. Every act and every ruling have an impact which ripples through to the farthest corners of industry and the labour force. So it is with this Public Service case. A score of left wing unions took out Press space in newspapers around the nation a couple of weeks ago to declare publicly their support for the Public Service unions' case. They did not do it out of a passionate love for wage justice for public servants. Indeed, in the aristocracy of labour, the hard core left wing unions tend to be rather condescending and look down on public servants as workers. Let there be no mistake about this. Those left wing unions declared their support for the Public Service because of hopeful precedent-the precedent that the case could set for the rest of the trade union movement to exploit. They hope that unionists in the Government's employ will set the precedent that under the accord, simply put, anything goes. They will stretch, bend, distort and circumvent the accord so completely that it will be an empty document, a hollow myth-a myth that has perished because it has no intrinsic truth, strength, authority or utility.

Then, commentators will ask what the accord amounted to anyway. They will contemplate with faint curiosity the lengths to which the Government has gone to preserve the myth and they will ask: Why did it bother? The accord did not change a thing. It was a descriptive document, a public relations document, which merely described a brief and superficially balanced stage in the very ordinary relationship between the Hawke Government and the trade union movement. There exists no special relationship. This Hawke Government has a very ordinary relationship with the trade union movement. The signs are there for all to see and not just in anecdotal accounts of industrial conflict, nor in the statistics of the level of industrial disputation. Most starkly they are evident in recent employment statistics, which show that minor growth in employment levels which occurred in the first term of the Hawke Government has been arrested and that, most disturbingly, much of it was attributable to public sector job creation anyway-the dole recycling queues.

If there is a single reliable barometer as to the health of the economy and its industrial relations system, it is the labour market. That is the single barometer which tells one more about industrial relations and more about the health of the economy than anything else. Unfortunately for many thousands of people, this Government must carry the can on the labour market too because that market is looking decidedly sick. Unemployment is now stuck at about 8.5 per cent. Look at any economic indicator or statistic. Predictions from most reputable commentators are that unemployment statistics will stay around 8 or 9 per cent for the next 12 months. More than 600,000 of our fellow Australians are without work and, regrettably, many of them are facing increased periods of continuing unemployment. Also, 25 per cent of our young people have failed to find jobs. They are part of that miserable present and part of that bleak future.

Over the coming session, the Opposition intends to articulate a different approach. We are not interested in myths; we are interested in realities. On behalf of the Opposition, I hope to make very clear the choice between its approach and that of this failing Government. In the employment and industrial relations portfolio, more than any other, the consequences of the wrong choice become evident. We must get our industrial relations system right in Australia or we are consigning ourselves and our children to mediocrity, general improverishment and massive social decline. We are on the threshold of becoming not just a second rate but a third rate nation unless we can get our industrial relations system right. As I said at the outset, I have absolutely no faith in the ability of this Government to do that.

Interestingly enough, the accord is a useful framework through which we can explore the alternative courses. The Government has tried to sell it as a document of equity and social justice. It has had its fair share of success in the marketing task, but its true nature, its shallowness and its emptiness are being relentlessly exposed. What is more, those aspects are being exposed not just by the Opposition, not even particularly by critics in the media, but by the hard, cold evidence of strikes, economic malaise and continuing high levels of unemployment and by the harsh reality that is coming home to the Australian people. If anything, the accord is a document written and negotiated by the employed for the benefit of the employed. It is a document which cuts out unemployed Australians. It shuts them out of the economy, which exploits their lack of organisation and consequently their voicelessness. If there is one thing that I wish to do while I am Opposition spokesman in this portfolio, it is to communicate and articulate the interests of the unemployed. If there is one view I seek to put loudly and clearly over and over again to members of this House and to the Australian public at large, it is that of unemployed Australians-young, old, middle aged, skilled, unskilled, migrant and indigenous. I seek to incorporate their views and their voice into a discourse which under this Government has been the sole preserve of the already employed. Their voice and their views will lend support to the revitalisation of the Australian economy, the restructuring of the industrial relations system and the redistribution of opportunity in the labour market that only the coalition's approach, as we enunciate it, can achieve. I commend our approach and our policies to honourable members and to the people of Australia. I am sure that over the next three years they will receive sufficient support to put us on the Government benches and those who have failed yet again on the Opposition benches.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH PARLIAMENTARY CONFERENCE, ISLE OF MAN, 1984

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch Delegation to the Thirtieth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, Isle of Man, in September-October 1984 and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the House that the Douglas conference was most successful, both for the Association generally and from the point of view of the Commonwealth of Australia branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. In terms of the Association, the most significant matter was the continuation of consideration of the report of the working party on the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and the future. Certain decisions were made by the General Assembly at its meeting in Nairobi in 1983, and remaining matters were considered most thoroughly in Douglas, culminating in the decision of the conference, by an overwhelming majority, to adopt the working party report.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members may recall that the Commonwealth of Australia branch was heavily involved in the decision to establish the working party and played a major role in its deliberations. Members of the delegation were heavily involved in consideration of the report by the conference. The adoption of the report will be very important for the future of the Association, covering as it does such matters as representation on the executive and means by which savings in expenditure could be achieved in the operation of the Association.

Members of the House should also be aware that the new Chairman of the Executive Committee is the distinguished Speaker of the Indian Lok Sabha, Dr the Hon. Bal Ram Jakhar, who participated heavily in the work of the working party and who is a distinguished member of the Association.

The conference was both productive and enjoyable. It was productive in enabling some 188 delegates and committee members representing 95 branches to debate and discuss a wide range of topical parliamentary, economic, governmental and social issues. I think it could also be said that some delegates came to the conference questioning the value of the CPA or the value of such a conference conducted by it. I think those delegates with doubts who took part in the formal as well as the informal discussions came away from the Isle of Man believing that there is great value in a body such as the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, a value that is derived from not only the formal discussions, but also the informal contacts that are made.

In the formal discussions, what I found fascinating-and I believe other delegates found it of interest too-was the great commonality of concern about a large number of issues, a concern common to parliamentarians from countries large and small, from countries of the developed world and the developing world and the undeveloped world, from island state to continental nation. The identification of that common concern was very valuable when we realised that we shared similar interests although we came from such diverse countries.

In addition to the formal discussions, great value was gained by all members of the Australian delegation, as well as other delegations, from their participation in informal meetings with parliamentarians from the countries which I described earlier. I felt very heartened and encouraged by the results of the discussions on the working party's paper and from the feeling of strength that was gained from the discussions between members representing the 95 branches attending that conference. The efforts of the officers of the Isle of Man branch, the members of the Tynwald, the Parliament of the Isle of Man, who participated so wholeheartedly in conference activities, and of the Manx people themselves, all combined in ensuring a particularly enjoyable and fruitful conference. With my fellow delegates, I am deeply appreciative of the generosity and hospitality of our hosts.

I also place on record the appreciation of the members of the Australian delegation for the leadership provided by the President of the Senate, Senator Douglas McClelland, who was the leader of the delegation. He was a significant figure at the conference and enjoyed the respect and friendship of a wide range of delegates and observers. I say without hesitation that the Australian delegation took an active part in the conference debates, in the deliberations of the General Assembly and in those informal contacts to which I have referred. I appreciate the efforts of all my fellow delegates in this regard.

I make one further comment to acknowledge the work of Sir Robin Vanderfelt, for whom this conference might have been his last as Secretary-General of the Association. I place on record our delegation's appreciation of his leadership at that conference as well as, I am sure, the appreciation of many of our predecessors in our recognition of the great services he has rendered to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association at its conferences and to the Australian delegates who have attended them.

Any delegation of six members of parliament relies very heavily on its staff and I take this opportunity to record my thanks and the thanks of members of the delegation to Mr Bernard Wright, a clerk assistant in this House-I am pleased to see he is on duty at this moment in the House-who acted as secretary to the delegation, and to Mr Keirin Schneemann, the regional secretary of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, Australian region, who attended the conference as an observer and acted as an adviser to our dele- gation. Their assistance was of great value to all members of the delegation.

I include one other note of thanks. One does not get to a place such as the Isle of Man without an immense amount of organisation, through the booking of air tickets and the making of reservations. The other day, I received a letter from Qantas Airways Ltd to say that Ian Grow has been given other responsibilities and has been moved from the position he has held for some time as the principal officer handling parliamentary bookings on Qantas overseas flights. For my part, and, I think, also for members of the delegation, I record my appreciation for his assistance to the delegation and for his assistance over a number of years to many members of this House and, no doubt, of the Senate, for the work that he did in making our travel arrangements so easy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a member of the Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation to the Thirtieth Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference which, as was mentioned, was held in Douglas, Isle of Man, I would like to support very strongly and sincerely the comments made by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who was the deputy leader of the delegation. As he said, there is value in both the formal and the informal contacts made there and all members who went to that conference were very impressed with the standard of the conference. This was my first opportunity of being a member of the delegation representing this Parliament overseas. My impressions are that the Australian delegation to the CPA conference was held in very high regard by the other parliamentarians at the conference. It was interesting to observe that we were, I think, the only country that hosted a special function, apart from the host nation, for all other parliamentarians. It was well attended, I might add.

SPEECH.PARA: On this occasion, it would be fitting for me to give due credit to the leader of the delegation, Senator Douglas McClelland, the President of the Senate. He had an important role in promoting an Australian perspective in both the conference debates and the deliberations of the General Assembly, and I think it is fitting that recognition be paid to his part in the total conference.

I was fortunate in being the first cab off the rank, in terms of having the opportunity of being the first Australian speaker at the first plenary session, which dealt with the Commonwealth, the arms race and world peace. The general purport of the debate was that the Commonwealth should play an active intermediary role in the pursuit of international peace and disarmament, to establish a safe global climate for economic development.

Mention must be made-and it has been made by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson)-of the tremendous hospitality received from our Manx hosts. That and the organisational arrangements for the conference made all overseas visitors and delegates feel very much at home. I would like to express my appreciation of their generosity and their hospitality. I trust that when we host the Thirty-fourth Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in 1988, which I hope will be a good vintage year--

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be the start of our third term.
—That is right. I hope that those entrusted with the organisation of that conference will pay considerable attention to the way in which the small Isle of Man CPA organised its conference.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to say how privileged I was to attend that conference. I would like again to share the comments made by the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Sturt, in his tributes to Mr Wright and Mr Schneemann, because certainly they played an important role in making sure that the Australian delegates to the conference were very well settled in at the conference and in the arrangements made before that conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I feel privileged to have taken part in this Commonwealth Parliamentary Association delegation to the Isle of Man; to have enjoyed the amity and cordiality prevailing among the Australian delegates, and to have enjoyed a part of this world which must be described as quite exquisite. The Isle of Man is a gem in the Irish Sea. On a clear day, from Mount Snaefell, a mere 2,000 feet, one can gaze around the horizon and simultaneously witness the coastlines of Ireland, Scotland and Wales, and one is reminded of the contrast with this vast country.

SPEECH.PARA: That was not the only contrast. We were mindful, of course, that we rejoiced in a community which has treasured and has enjoyed the longest standing democratic parliament in the world-the Tynwald-for a period of over 1,000 years. I was particularly impressed with the nature of the character of the members of the community whose company we enjoyed. Whilst they were remarkably efficient and purposeful in their address to the essentials attended upon the visit to their small country of some 164 delegates and attendant staff, they manifested a quality which reminded me very much of this country of ours perhaps 50 years ago. I must admit to a silent lament that probably in 50 years time they will enjoy and suffer the experiences which this country of ours presently suffers.

I mention the purpose of address, the most effective way in which they accommodated the reasonable expectations of the delegations, yet strangely enough, as efficient and deliberate as they were, they manifested a human quality which almost teetered on insouciance. I wonder where this exquisite place in the sun may end up as man hurtles to his destination, which is not yet determined. I enjoyed the company of my colleagues. I think the CPA delegation acquitted itself well. Whilst men of diverse cultures and characters can come together in common accord and discuss matters of common interest, our overall cause must be advanced as a consequence.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the Victorian election is on. I realise I am not meant to be speaking here tonight, but it is the fiftieth anniversary of Qantas Airways Ltd today. The first international flight Qantas made was on 25 February 1935. I think it is most important for all Australians to remember the fact. No doubt many parliamentarians, including the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), make many trips around the world with Qantas in the big jumbo jets and think nothing of it, but it is to be remembered that the Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services commenced its services in western Queensland more than 50 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The service was initially established by a number of people in that part of the world who saw the need for an airline to service western Queensland and the Northern Territory, to give those people much needed mail services and food services, which they were not able to get in those days. TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Conservation Foundation has recommended to the Federal Government that it take up an initiative with its 15 contracting Antarctic treaty partners in forming a conservation convention for the continent of Antarctica, with the main aim of creating an Antarctica world park. The ACF has also suggested to the Federal Government that it propose to its treaty partners that there be a nomination of all parts of Antarctica by those claiming sovereignty for inclusion on the World Heritage List. Those areas which are not the subject of historic sovereignty claims could be managed by a special park authority. I would like to strongly support the ACF's proposals. The proposed world park could cover not only 14 million square kilometres, over one-and-a-half times the size of Australia, but also the continental shelf and possibly also the fishing zones. Different areas of the world park could be zoned for different purposes, such as scientific bases, nature reserves and tourism. Military activities of all types, including nuclear dumping and the testing of nuclear devices, would be totally banned.

SPEECH.PARA: The eight main advantages for the establishment of a world park are as follows: First, it will result in the maintenance of a pattern of activity in Antarctica which has been successful in achieving scientific co-operation and conservation. Secondly, it will maintain Antarctica as a zone of peace. Thirdly, it will avoid increased tension between nations over access to Antarctica's minerals. Fourthly, it will avoid large expenditures on the search for minerals. Fifthly, it will conserve the Antarctic environment in its natural state as the last great wilderness and a global ecological buffer. Sixthly, it will set an example of environmental restraint which will be of value for international and domestic policy elsewhere. Seventhly, it will result in an earlier turn to renewable sources of energy and, eighthly, it will not prevent Antarctic minerals from being exploited if there were to be a demonstrated need for access to them in the case of a genuine world emergency. Australia, being one of the initial treaty nations and because of its geographical closeness to Antarctica, can take the lead in taking up the world park proposal.

One of my concerns in relation to Antarctica is the threat which mining and oil exploration and the subsequent development of such industries could pose for the unique environment of the Antarctic. In the case of oil there is the major problem which oil spills could mean for marine life. Virtually all marine life is based on the marine environment. Oil degrades slowly in the freezing waters of the Antarctic and the debilitating effect of oil on the swarms of krill, upon which all other forms of Antarctic life depend, would be catastrophic. The flow of air and water throughout the region also poses threats for the fishing industries of Chile and Argentina. Mining and oil drilling would require extensive infrastructure for the housing of workers and for transport and storage facilities. Competition for the limited space could cause great threats to the environment, involving pollution and disturbance to the natural fauna. It is vital that the treaty nations agree to consider the conservation of the continent as an option which could run parallel to the consideration of a minerals regime while at the same time agreeing to a moratorium on mining until full consideration has been given to the conservation option.

As an article by Dr Geoff Mosley, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, in Habitat some months ago indicated, time for the declaration of Antarctica as a world park is rapidly running out. If the Australian Government does not take the initiative now, the environmental beauty of the continent of Antarctica may be lost for all time to exploitative interests and the destructive forces of pollution and despoilation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let the opportunity of the last couple of minutes of this adjournment debate go by without referring to the last speech. I refer to the area of Dunkley. The Victorian Government, in the last three or four months, announced a huge increase in expenditure on the Frankston hospital. At long last the hole in the ground at Frankston will be filled up. Liberal governments have failed for 27 years to fill that hole. They kept offering.
—Tell us what you did to the Mornington Bush Nursing Hospital.

—If the honourable member really wants to know, it was I who made successful representations to the Minister for Health to allow the Bush Nursing Hospital's case to be heard here. It was not a member of the National Party. It was not a member of the Liberal Party. It was I, when I was the member for Flinders. Claims that the Cain Labor Government will not be there on 2 March are completely false. This will be proved in the next four or five days. Over last month we heard about Jeff Kennett's foot and mouth disease. It is spreading to Canberra. I can hear it suffers all over the place. The candidate for Frankston South, Geoff Holland, is an excellent candidate. I cannot remember the name of the Liberal candidate, but Geoff Holland is the one who will win Frankston South. In Mornington we have David Hassett. He has represented the electorate of Dromana on the Mornington Peninsula excellently over the past three years and will represent Mornington for the next four years. In Dromana we have another excellent candidate, Allison Ogden. Dromana is a part of the Flinders electorate and is a beautiful area. I am quite certain that Allison will win there handsomely. Frankston, of course, is the hub of the peninsula and is in the beautiful electorate of Dunkley. The Mornington City Council has done more in community employment program projects than any other council on the peninsula. It has to be congratulated in the House for the excellent work it has done to try to alleviate the situation of those in our society who are disadvantaged.
